member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling
member.summary: Represents the strategy to be used with frames of different sizes.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling.ErrorIfDiffers
member.summary: Specifies that if an input frame has a different size, then an exception should be thrown.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling.Center
member.summary: Specifies that smaller or larger frames should be centered. Possibly exceeding areas will be clipped.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling.Resize
member.summary: Specifies that frames should be resized to the actual size of the animation.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode
member.summary: Represents the looping mode of an animation.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode.PingPong
member.summary: Specifies that added frames should be played back and forth.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode.Repeat
member.summary: Specifies that the animation should be looped.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode.PlayOnce
member.summary: Specifies that the animation should be played only once.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode
member.summary: Represents the compression behavior of the class.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.Auto
member.summary: Represents the automatic adaptive mode. The internally used code table might be regularly cleared.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.DoNotClear
member.summary: Indicates that once the internally used code table is full, it is not maintained anymore and all remaining codes are written using 12 bit code size. If codes so far can be re-used, then the result can be more compact than with mode; otherwise, the result can be even longer than in mode. This option might not be tolerated by some decoders.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.DoNotIncreaseBitSize
member.summary: Indicates that all written codes must use the same bit size (3 to 9 bits, depending on palette size). It uses less memory but it may lead to poor compression, especially with palettes using no more than 4 colors.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.Uncompressed
member.summary: Indicates that the should not use any compression. It uses the least memory but the result can be really long.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod
member.summary: Indicates the way in which the graphic is to be treated after being displayed.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.NotSpecified
member.summary: No disposal specified. The decoder is not required to take any action.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.DoNotDispose
member.summary: Do not dispose. The graphic is to be left in place.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.RestoreToBackground
member.summary: Restore to background color. The area used by the graphic must be restored to the background color. If there is no global palette, or the corresponding image has transparent color, then the virtual screen is always cleared to transparent.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.RestoreToPrevious
member.summary: Restore to previous. The decoder is required to restore the area overwritten by the graphic with what was there prior to rendering the graphic.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ArrayPoolingStrategy
member.summary: Represents the possible values for the BitmapDataFactory.PoolingStrategy property, which specifies the array pooling strategies for the self-allocating CreateBitmapData overloads in the class.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ArrayPoolingStrategy.Never
member.summary: Indicates that no array pooling occurs when creating instances by the self-allocating factory methods. This strategy will always use the best matching element type for the underlying buffer.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ArrayPoolingStrategy.IfByteArrayBased
member.summary: Specifies that array pooling occurs only if the natural buffer element type of the created instance is byte anyway. This is the case for indexed pixel formats in the enumaration.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ArrayPoolingStrategy.IfCanUseByteArray
member.summary: Specifies that array pooling always occurs if the created instance can use a byte array as its buffer. This is true for all pixel formats as long as the size of the underlying buffer does not exceed the maximum size of a byte array. Please note that the default array pool may not cache large arrays, and that accessing the reinterpreted elements may be slightly slower than using the best matching element type.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ArrayPoolingStrategy.AnyElementType
member.summary: Uses array pooling (if available on the current platform) for any element type. This may consume more memory than the other strategies, but there is no performance penalty for reinterpreting the elements.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AutoStrengthMode
member.summary:
Represents the behavior of ditherers with configurable strength when auto strength is used.
See the Remarks section of the OrderedDitherer.ConfigureStrength method for more details and some examples regarding dithering strength.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AutoStrengthMode.Default
member.summary: The auto strength mode is determined by the property of the corresponding quantizing session. If it returns , then the default strategy is ; otherwise, it is .

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AutoStrengthMode.Constant
member.summary: Represents an auto strength strategy where strength is calibrated to a fix value that assures that neither the black nor the white colors will suffer from overdithering. This is the default auto strength strategy when quantizing in the sRGB color space and it usually works fine if palette entries are evenly distributed in the sRGB color space.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AutoStrengthMode.Interpolated
member.summary: Represents an auto strength strategy where strength is calibrated both for white and black colors individually so none of them suffer from overdithering. During dithering the actual applied strength will be a dynamic value for each pixels using interpolation between the white and black strengths based on the pixel brightness. This is the default auto strength strategy when quantizing in the linear color space.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.KnownPixelFormat
member.summary: Represents pixel formats with built-in support. For custom formats you can use the type when applicable.

remarks.note: The enumeration contains all formats that the System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat enumeration also has, though some fields have different values and the matching names do not necessarily represent the same pixel layout either. For example, in this library wide formats, such as , use the full 16 bit per color channel range and the same gamma correction as the 8-bit per channel formats, whereas System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format64bppArgb might represent a different range or gamma correction, depending on the operating system.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.KnownPixelFormat.Undefined
member.summary: The pixel format is undefined.

summary.para: Represents the indexed 1 bit per pixel format. The corresponding color palette can have up to 2 colors.
Bit order: bits are filled up from the most significant bit to the least significant bit within a byte.
Indexed pixel formats are represented by the type where every palette entry is a .
Represents the indexed 4 bit per pixel format. The corresponding color palette can have up to 16 colors.
Bit order: even pixels occupy the high bits of a byte, whereas odd pixels are in the low bits.
Indexed pixel formats are represented by the type where every palette entry is a .
Represents the indexed 8 bit per pixel format. The corresponding color palette can have up to 256 colors.
Indexed pixel formats are represented by the type where every palette entry is a .
Represents a 16 bit per pixel grayscale format. The color information specifies 65536 shades of gray.
The closest color type that can represent this pixel format without losing information is .
Represents a 16 bit per pixel RGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 5 bits per pixel and 1 bit is unused.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 5 blue, 5 green, 5 red bits and 1 unused bit. As a binary value a pixel can be specified as 0b_X_RRRRR_GGGGG_BBBBB on little endian CPUs where X is the ignored most significant bit and BBBBB is the blue component at the least significant bits.
The closest color type that can represent this pixel format without losing information is .
Represents a 16 bit per pixel RGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 5, 6 and 5 bits per pixel, respectively.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 5 blue, 6 green and 5 red bits. As a binary value a pixel can be specified as 0b_RRRRR_GGGGGG_BBBBB on little endian CPUs where BBBBB is the blue component at the least significant bits.
The closest color type that can represent this pixel format without losing information is .
Represents a 16 bit per pixel ARGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 5 bits per pixel along with 1 bit for alpha.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 5 blue, 5 green, 5 red bits and 1 alpha bit. As a binary value a pixel can be specified as 0b_A_RRRRR_GGGGG_BBBBB on little endian CPUs where A is the most significant bit and BBBBB is the blue component at the least significant bits.
The closest color type that can represent this pixel format without losing information is .
Represents a 24 bit per pixel RGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 8 bits per pixel.
Bit order from LSB to MSB: 8 blue, 8 green and 8 red bits.
The closest color type that can represent this pixel format without losing information is .
Represents a 32 bit per pixel RGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 8 bits per pixel. The remaining 8 bits are not used.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 8 blue, 8 green, 8 red and 8 unused bits. As a hex value a pixel can be specified as 0x_XX_RR_GG_BB on little endian CPUs where XX is the unused most significant byte and BB is the blue component at the least significant byte.
The closest color type that can represent this pixel format without losing information is .
Represents a 32 bit per pixel ARGB color format where alpha, red, green and blue channels use 8 bits per pixel.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 8 blue, 8 green, 8 red and 8 alpha bits. As a hex value a pixel can be specified as 0x_AA_RR_GG_BB on little endian CPUs where BB is the blue component at the least significant byte.
The matching color type that represents this pixel format directly is .

Represents a 32 bit per pixel ARGB color format where alpha, red, green and blue channels use 8 bits per pixel. The red, green, and blue components are premultiplied, according to the alpha component.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 8 blue, 8 green, 8 red and 8 alpha bits. As a hex value a pixel can be specified as 0x_AA_RR_GG_BB on little endian CPUs where BB is the blue component at the least significant byte.
The matching color type that represents this pixel format directly is .
Represents a 48 bit per pixel RGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 16 bits per pixel.
Bit order from LSB to MSB: 16 blue, 16 green and 16 red bits.
The closest color type that can represent this pixel format without losing information is .
Represents a 64 bit per pixel ARGB color format where alpha, red, green and blue channels use 16 bits per pixel.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 16 blue, 16 green, 16 red and 16 alpha bits. As a hex value a pixel can be specified as 0x_AAAA_RRRR_GGGG_BBBB on little endian CPUs where BBBB is the blue component at the least significant couple of bytes.
The matching color type that represents this pixel format directly is .

Represents a 64 bit per pixel ARGB color format where alpha, red, green and blue channels use 16 bits per pixel. The red, green, and blue components are premultiplied, according to the alpha component.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 16 blue, 16 green, 16 red and 16 alpha bits. As a hex value a pixel can be specified as 0x_AAAA_RRRR_GGGG_BBBB on little endian CPUs where BBBB is the blue component at the least significant couple of bytes.
The matching color type that represents this pixel format directly is .
Represents a 96 bit per pixel RGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 32 bits per pixel.
Bit order from LSB to MSB: 32 red, 32 green and 32 blue bits. The color components are floating point values between 0 and 1 in the linear color space.
The closest color type that can represent this pixel format without losing information is .
Represents a 128 bit per pixel RGBA color format where alpha, red, green and blue channels use 32 bits per pixel.
Bit order from LSB to MSB: 32 red, 32 green, 32 blue and 32 alpha bits. The color components are floating point values between 0 and 1 in the linear color space.
The matching color type that represents this pixel format directly is .

Represents a 128 bit per pixel RGBA color format where alpha, red, green and blue channels use 32 bits per pixel. The red, green, and blue components are premultiplied, according to the alpha component.
Bit order from LSB to MSB: 32 red, 32 green, 32 blue and 32 alpha bits. The color components are floating point values between 0 and 1 in the linear color space.
The matching color type that represents this pixel format directly is .
Represents a 8 bit per pixel grayscale format. The color information specifies 256 shades of gray.
The closest color type that can represent this pixel format without losing information is .

Represents a 32 bit per pixel grayscale format. The color information specifies about one billion shades of gray between 0 and 1 where the largest difference between two representable values is about 0.00000001 (10-8).
The closest color type that can represent this pixel format without losing information is .

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.WorkingColorSpace
member.summary:
Represents the preferred working color space for various operations such as alpha blending, measuring distance of colors, interpolation, quantizing, dithering and some other operations. The working color space can be specified independently of the color space of the actual pixel format of an instance.
See the online help for image examples.

remarks.para:
The working color space can be specified at various places in KGy SOFT Drawing Libraries:
At the lowest level, you can specify it when blending colors manually, for example by the ColorExtensions.Blend method.
instances have a property, which can be set by the factory methods such as the BitmapDataFactory.CreateBitmapData methods or by the GetReadWriteBitmapData methods for the technology-specific bitmap types. The IBitmapData.WorkingColorSpace property is considered when setting pixels with transparency and the pixel format of the bitmap data does not support transparency so the color has to be blended with IBitmapData.BackColor. The color space of the target bitmap is considered also when drawing shapes, or when bitmap data instances are drawn into each other.
The class also has a property, which is used by the and methods.
Quantizers also have their own working color space configuration. You can use the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.ConfigureColorSpace and OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.ConfigureColorSpace methods to configure the working color space of the built-in quantizers of KGy SOFT Drawing Libraries.
Ditherers may also have specific behavior for the different color spaces. The ditherer implementations in KGy SOFT Drawing Libraries always take the working color space of the corresponding quantizer exposed by the IQuantizingSession.WorkingColorSpace property.

example.para: Most common color representations (just like the or types that use 8 bit color channels) use the sRGB color space that has gamma corrected color values. In a color type that uses the sRGB color space the consecutive RGB values don't represent linear light intensity increase. Instead, a gamma correction of approximately γ = 2.2 is applied to the actual light intensity, so it is adjusted for the perception of the human eye (in fact, the sRGB color space is linear for the darkest values and uses a γ = 2.4 correction above a threshold limit so the overall average is somewhere around 2.2). This representation helps to distribute RGB values so that 50% represents the apparently half-bright tones:

term.div: Grayscale color shades. The difference of RGB values between the neighboring shades is constant in the sRGB color space, resulting an apparently linear gradient with half-gray tones at the middle.

example.para: Blending partially transparent (alpha) colors in the sRGB color space ends up in incorrect results, though it is not always obvious. The most apparent incorrect results are for colors that have disjunct RGB values, for which the result is typically too dark.

th.div: Blending in the sRGB color space
Blending in the linear color space

td.div: Result of blending colors in the sRGB color space. The vertical bars are opaque, whereas the horizontal ones have 50% transparency. Blending colors with disjunct RGB components often produce too dark results.
Result of blending colors in the linear color space. The result seems much more natural. Note that horizontal bars still have 50% transparency, though they seem brighter now.

Color hues with alpha gradient. As the image contains transparency the blending with the background is performed by your browser.
(Side note: just like at the grayscale gradient above, the color gradients also have constant RGB differences between the horizontal neighboring pixels in the sRGB color space. The examples below are different only in alpha blending but all of them have the same sRGB color gradients.)
Color hues blended with white background in the sRGB color space. If the alpha image in the row above looks like this, then your browser blends colors in the sRGB color space.
Color hues blended with white background in the linear color space.
Color hues blended with black background in the sRGB color space.
Color hues blended with black background in the linear color space. Note that much more colors are visible in the darker regions.

example.para: To blend sRGB colors correctly, the source colors must be converted to the linear color space first, and then the blended result has to be converted back to the sRGB color space. This has an additional cost, which is often omitted even by professional image processing applications, libraries and even by web browsers.
example.note: Even though blending in the sRGB color space is not quite correct, some pixel formats are optimized exactly for doing that. With premultiplied sRGB pixel formats sRGB blending is very fast, and forcing color correct blending is particularly expensive. Use such pixel formats only when it is really justified, for example when this is the fastest or default format for a rendering engine (which is almost always the case, including GDI+, WPF, UWP, WinUI, Skia and many other engines). If you want to use color correct blending the best if you use pixel formats with linear gamma (indicated by the property), or for sRGB pixel formats try to avoid premultiplied formats to prevent the overhead of unnecessary conversions back and forth.
example.para: When reducing the number of colors to some specified set of colors (either by using a of predefined entries or some custom quantizer function) measuring the distance between colors may return different results depending on the used color space. Looking up for the nearest colors in the sRGB color space tends to turn the darker shades too bright, though the more colors the quantizer uses the less noticeable the difference is.

th.div: Quantizing in the sRGB color space
Quantizing in the linear color space

td.div: Original test image "Girl with a Pearl Earring"
Quantizing by black and white palette in the sRGB color space.
Quantizing by black and white palette in the linear color space.
Quantizing by RGB111 palette in the sRGB color space.
Quantizing by RGB111 palette in the linear color space.
Quantizing by system default 8 BPP palette in the sRGB color space. For more colors the difference is much less noticeable but the background is slightly brighter than in the original image.
Quantizing by system default 8 BPP palette in the linear color space. For more colors the difference is much less noticeable but the background is slightly darker than in the sRGB result.

example.para: When quantizing is combined with dithering, the ditherers may also respect the working color space of the quantizers. Similarly to the non-dithered results, the difference between working in the sRGB or linear color space gets less and less noticeable with using more and more colors.

th.div: Quantizing with dithering in the sRGB color space
Quantizing with dithering in the linear color space

td.div: Original test image "Girl with a Pearl Earring"

Quantizing by black and white palette in the sRGB color space using Bayer 8x8 dithering. The result is too bright. Please note though that if your browser resizes the image in the sRGB color space it might appear correct, in which case make sure you open it in a new tab and set the zoom to 100%.

Quantizing by black and white palette in the linear color space using Bayer 8x8 dithering. The result has correct brightness. Please note though that if your browser resizes the image in the sRGB color space it might appear too dark, in which case make sure you open it in a new tab and set the zoom to 100%.

Quantizing by RGB111 palette in the sRGB color space using Floyd-Steinberg dithering. The result is too bright. Please note though that if your browser resizes the image in the sRGB color space it might appear correct, in which case make sure you open it in a new tab and set the zoom to 100%.

Quantizing by RGB111 palette in the linear color space using Floyd-Steinberg dithering. The result has correct brightness. Please note though that if your browser resizes the image in the sRGB color space it might appear too dark, in which case make sure you open it in a new tab and set the zoom to 100%.

Quantizing by system default 8 BPP palette in the sRGB color space using Floyd-Steinberg dithering. The background is slightly brighter than in the original image but due to the number of colors the difference is barely noticeable.

Quantizing by system default 8 BPP palette in the linear color space using Floyd-Steinberg dithering. Due to the number of colors the difference is barely noticeable between the sRGB and the linear result.

example.para: When resizing images with some interpolation the working color space may also affect the result. When resizing true color images the difference might be negligible; however, if the source image has only a few colors with high frequency areas (typically dithered images as above) the working color space used for the resizing makes a noticeable difference.

th.div: Resizing in the sRGB color space
Resizing in the linear color space

td.div: Test image "Girl with a Pearl Earring" quantized by RGB111 palette in the linear color space using Bayer 8x8 dithering.

Resizing the quantized image with bicubic interpolation in the sRGB color space. The result is too dark. Ironically, if the source image had been quantized in the sRGB color space so it was too bright, then the resized result would seem quite correct.
Resizing the quantized image with bicubic interpolation in the linear color space. The result preserved the original brightness.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.WorkingColorSpace.Default
member.summary: Represents the default color space mode most optimal for the current operation or actual color space. When working with entries or an the default option always chooses the sRGB color space. When working with an directly, then the selected working color space depends on the of the target bitmap data.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.WorkingColorSpace.Linear
member.summary: Indicates that the linear color space should be used when performing operations on colors. If the actual color space of the source is sRGB, then the operation has some overhead due to the conversions back and forth.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.WorkingColorSpace.Srgb
member.summary: Indicates that the sRGB color space should be used when performing operations on colors.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataExtensions.Clone(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadableBitmapData)
member.summary: Gets the clone of the specified with identical size.
member.param: An instance to be cloned.
member.returns: An instance that represents the clone of the specified .

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overload to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

member.exception: is .
member.overloads:
The overloads of the Clone method can be grouped into the following categories:
The ones without and parameters attempt to create an exact copy of the original bitmap data. The original pixel format is attempted to be preserved even for custom formats, which may succeed if the property was set to when the bitmap data was created.
The overloads that have a parameter create a copy with the specified pixel format. The original color depth is attempted to be preserved as much as possible, even between different pixel formats with wide colors.
The overloads with a parameter allow to create a copy only of a portion of the source bitmap.
If an overload has an parameter, then it allows limiting the set of colors of the result even if the format would allow more colors.
If the result pixel format has a low bit-per-pixel value, or you use a quantizer and you want to preserve the details as much as possible, then look for the overloads that have an parameter.
To be able to configure the degree of parallelism, cancellation or progress reporting, look for the overloads whose last parameter is a ParallelConfig instance.
Some overloads have an IAsyncContext parameter. These methods are special ones and are designed to be used from your custom asynchronous methods where cloning is just one step of potentially multiple operations. But you can also use these overloads to force synchronous execution on a single thread. See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.
All of these methods block the caller on the current thread. For asynchronous call you can use the CloneAsync overloads (on .NET Framework 4.0 and above), or the old-fashioned BeginClone methods that work on every platform target.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataExtensions.Clone(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadableBitmapData,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.KnownPixelFormat,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte)
member.summary: Gets the clone of the specified with identical size and the specified and color settings.
member.param: An instance to be cloned.
The desired pixel format of the result.

If does not support alpha or supports only single-bit alpha, then specifies the color of the background. Source pixels with alpha, which will be opaque in the result will be blended with this color. The Color32.A property of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

If can represent only single-bit alpha or is an indexed format and the target palette contains a transparent color, then specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A property, under which the color is considered transparent. If 0, then the result will not have transparent pixels. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: An instance that represents the clone of the specified .

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overload to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.
remarks.para: This overload automatically quantizes colors if represents a narrower set of colors than . To use a custom quantizer use the overloads with an parameter.
Color depth can be preserved if the target format can represent the colors of the source format without losing information.

If represents an indexed format, then the target palette is taken from if it also has a palette of no more entries than the target indexed format can have; otherwise, a default palette will be used based on . To specify the desired palette of the result use the overload.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the ConvertPixelFormat(Image, PixelFormat, Color, byte) extension method for some examples. The ConvertPixelFormat extensions work the same way for Images as the Clone extensions for instances.

does not specify a valid format.

A that specifies the portion of the to be cloned.
The desired pixel format of the result.
An optional instance to determine the colors of the result. If and is an indexed format, then a default palette and quantization logic will be used.

The ditherer to be used. Might be ignored if is not specified and represents an at least 24 bits-per-pixel size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An instance that represents the clone of the specified .

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overload to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.
remarks.para: If can represent a narrower set of colors, then the result will be automatically quantized to its color space, even if there is no specified. To use dithering a must be explicitly specified though.
If is specified but it uses more/different colors than can represent, then the result will eventually be quantized to , though the result may have a poorer quality than expected.
Color depth can be preserved if is not specigied and the target format can represent the colors of the source format without losing information.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the ConvertPixelFormat(Image, PixelFormat, IQuantizer?, IDitherer?) extension method for some examples. The ConvertPixelFormat extensions work the same way for Images as the Clone extensions for instances.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataExtensions.Clone(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadableBitmapData,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.KnownPixelFormat,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte,KGySoft.Threading.ParallelConfig)
member.summary: Gets the clone of the specified with identical size and the specified and color settings.
member.param: An instance to be cloned.
The desired pixel format of the result.

If does not support alpha or supports only single-bit alpha, then specifies the color of the background. Source pixels with alpha, which will be opaque in the result will be blended with this color. The Color32.A property of the background color is ignored.

If can represent only single-bit alpha or is an indexed format and the target palette contains a transparent color, then specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A property, under which the color is considered transparent. If 0, then the result will not have transparent pixels.

The configuration of the operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. If , then the degree of parallelization is configured automatically.
member.returns: An instance that represents the clone of the specified , or , if the operation was canceled and the ThrowIfCanceled property of the parameter was .

remarks.note: This method blocks the caller as it executes synchronously, though the parameter allows configuring the degree of parallelism, cancellation and progress reporting. Use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.
remarks.para: This overload automatically quantizes colors if represents a narrower set of colors than . To use a custom quantizer use the overloads with an parameter.
Color depth can be preserved if the target format can represent the colors of the source format without losing information.

If represents an indexed format, then the target palette is taken from if it also has a palette of no more entries than the target indexed format can have; otherwise, a default palette will be used based on . To specify the desired palette of the result use the overload.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the ConvertPixelFormat(Image, PixelFormat, Color, byte) extension method for some examples. The ConvertPixelFormat extensions work the same way for Images as the Clone extensions for instances.

does not specify a valid format.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataExtensions.Clone(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadableBitmapData,KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncContext,System.Nullable{System.Drawing.Rectangle})
member.summary: Gets the clone of the specified portion of , using a that may belong to a higher level, possibly asynchronous operation.
member.param: An instance to be cloned.
An IAsyncContext instance that contains information for asynchronous processing about the current operation. If , then the degree of parallelization is configured automatically.
A that specifies the portion of the to be cloned.
member.returns: An instance that represents the clone of the specified , or , if the operation was canceled.

remarks.para: This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

remarks.para: This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataExtensions.CopyTo(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadableBitmapData,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IWritableBitmapData,System.Drawing.Point,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizer,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IDitherer)
member.summary: Copies the into the without scaling and blending. This method works between any pair of source and target s and supports quantizing and dithering. To draw a bitmap data into another one with blending use the DrawInto methods instead.
member.param: The source to be copied into the .
The target into which should be copied.

The target location. Target size will be always the same as the source size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: Point.Empty.

An instance to be used. If not specified, then the copying operation might automatically pick a quantizer based on . This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The ditherer to be used. Might be ignored if is not specified and format has at least 24 bits-per-pixel size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overload to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginCopyTo or CopyToAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.
remarks.para: The copied area is automatically clipped if its size or makes it impossible to completely fit in the .

If can represent a narrower set of colors, then the result will be automatically quantized to the colors of the , even if there is no specified. To use dithering a must be explicitly specified though.
If is specified but it uses more/different colors than can represent, then the result will eventually be quantized to , though the result may have a poorer quality than expected.

member.exception: or is .
member.overloads:
The overloads of the CopyTo method can be grouped into the following categories:
The overloads with a parameter allow to copy only a portion of the source bitmap.
If an overload has an parameter, then it allows limiting the set of colors of the result even if the pixel format of the target would allow more colors.
If the target pixel format has a low bit-per-pixel value or you use a quantizer and you want to preserve the details as much as possible, then look for the overloads that have an parameter.
To be able to configure the degree of parallelism, cancellation or progress reporting, look for the overloads whose last parameter is a ParallelConfig instance.
One overload has an IAsyncContext parameter. That method is a special one and is designed to be used from your custom asynchronous methods where copying a bitmap is just one step of potentially multiple operations. But you can also use that overload to force synchronous execution on a single thread. See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.
All of these methods block the caller on the current thread. For asynchronous call you can use the CopyToAsync method (on .NET Framework 4.0 and above), or the old-fashioned BeginCopyTo method that works on every platform target.
Note that these methods preserve the original size of the source bitmap, and copy even the alpha pixels without alpha blending. To draw a bitmap data into another one with blending and potential resizing, use the DrawInto methods instead.

member.summary: Draws the into the without scaling, using blending. This method always preserves the source size in pixels, works between any pair of source and target s and supports quantizing and dithering. For scaling use the overloads with targetRectangle and parameters. To copy a bitmap data into another one without blending use the CopyTo methods instead.
member.param: The source to be drawn into the .
The target into which should be drawn.

The target location. Target size will be always the same as the source size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: Point.Empty.

An instance to be used for the drawing. If not specified, then the drawing operation might automatically pick a quantizer based on . This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The ditherer to be used for the drawing. Might be ignored if is not specified and format has at least 24 bits-per-pixel size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overload to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.
remarks.para: The image to be drawn is automatically clipped if its size or makes it impossible to completely fit in the .
must be an because it must be readable if blending is necessary. For write-only instances you can use the CopyTo methods.

If can represent a narrower set of colors, then the result will be automatically quantized to the colors of the , even if there is no specified. To use dithering a must be explicitly specified though.
If is specified but it uses more/different colors than can represent, then the result will eventually be quantized to , though the result may have a poorer quality than expected.

member.exception: or is .
member.overloads:
The overloads of the DrawInto method can be grouped into the following categories:
The ones that have a parameter for target location preserve the original size of the source bitmap.
The overloads with a and parameter allow to draw only a portion of the source bitmap, while they still preserve the original size.
There are overloads that allow resizing. These either have no parameter but one argument to allow drawing the whole source bitmap into the specified target rectangle; or, they have two parameters to allow drawing a portion of the source bitmap into the specified target rectangle. All of these methods have also a parameter that specifies the behavior of the potential shrinking or enlarging.
If an overload has an parameter, then it allows limiting the set of colors of the result even if the pixel format of the target would allow more colors.
If the target pixel format has a low bit-per-pixel value or you use a quantizer and you want to preserve the details as much as possible, then look for the overloads that have an parameter.
To be able to configure the degree of parallelism, cancellation or progress reporting, look for the overloads whose last parameter is a ParallelConfig instance.
A couple of overloads have an IAsyncContext parameter. These methods are special ones and are designed to be used from your custom asynchronous methods where drawing a bitmap into another one is just one step of potentially multiple operations. But you can also use these overloads to force synchronous execution on a single thread. See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.
All of these methods block the caller on the current thread. For asynchronous call you can use the DrawIntoAsync overloads (on .NET Framework 4.0 and above), or the old-fashioned BeginDrawInto methods that work on every platform target.
Note that these methods always perform an alpha blending (respecting the of the target bitmap) if the source contains alpha pixels. To copy a bitmap data into another one without blending and resizing, use the CopyTo methods instead.

member.summary: Draws the into the with scaling and blending, using a that may belong to a higher level, possibly asynchronous operation.

An IAsyncContext instance that contains information for asynchronous processing about the current operation.

, if the operation completed successfully.

remarks.para: This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.
See the overload for more details about the other parameters.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataExtensions.Clip(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadableBitmapData,System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Clips the specified using the specified . Unlike the Clone methods, this one returns a wrapper, providing access only to the specified region of the original .
member.param: The source bitmap data to be clipped.
A that specifies a region within the .
to dispose when the result is disposed; otherwise, .
member.returns: An that provides access only to the specified region withing the .
member.exception: is .
has no overlapping region with source bounds.

remarks.para: The property of the returned instance can be 0, indicating that the ReadRaw method cannot be used. It can occur if the left edge of the clipping is not zero.

Even if property of the returned instance is a nonzero value it can happen that it is too low to access all columns by the ReadRaw method. It can occur with indexed s if the right edge of the clipping is not on byte boundary.

member.summary: Gets the colors used in the specified . A limit can be defined in .
member.param: The , whose colors have to be returned. If it is indexed and the parameter is , then its palette entries are returned and is ignored.

A limit of the returned colors. If parameter is , then this parameter is ignored for indexed bitmaps. Use 0 for no limit. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 0.

to force scanning the actual image content even if the specified is indexed and has a palette. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An of entries.

remarks.note: This method blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the BeginGetColors or GetColorsAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to set up cancellation or for reporting progress.
remarks.para: Completely transparent pixels are considered the same regardless of their color information.

Every is supported, though wide color formats (, , and ) are quantized to 32 bit during the processing. To get the actual number of colors, which can be accurate even for wide color formats, use the GetColorCount method.

member.summary: Returns a new , which is the clone of the specified with transparent background.
member.param: The to convert to transparent.
member.returns: A new , which is the clone of the specified with transparent background.

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.
remarks.para: This method uses the bottom-left pixel to determine the background color, which must be completely opaque; otherwise, just an exact clone of will be returned.
This method always returns a new with pixel format.
To attempt to make an transparent without creating a new instance use the MakeTransparent method.
To force replacing even non-completely opaque pixels use the overload instead.
remarks.note: Please note that unlike the MakeOpaque method, this one changes exactly one color shade without any tolerance. For any customization use the Clone method with a quantizer created by the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.FromCustomFunction method.

remarks.note: Please note that unlike the MakeOpaque method, this one changes exactly one color shade without any tolerance. For any customization use the Clone method with a quantizer created by the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.FromCustomFunction method.

remarks.para: To reload the content use the BitmapDataFactory.Load method.
The saved content always preserves known s so the BitmapDataFactory.Load method can restore it the same way on any platform. Custom pixel formats are saved by a compatible known pixel format.

An implementation to be used for quantizing the specified .

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overload to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginQuantize or QuantizeAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.
remarks.para: This method quantizes the specified in place (its original content will be overwritten). To return a new instance use the Clone extension method instead.
If the or the palette of is not compatible with the colors of the specified , then the result may not be correct.
If has already the same set of colors that the specified , then it can happen that calling this method does not change the at all.

To use predefined colors or custom quantization functions use the static methods of the class.

To use an optimized palette of a specified number of colors adjusted for see the class.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataExtensions.MakeTransparent(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadWriteBitmapData)
member.summary: If possible, makes the background of this transparent, taking the bottom-left pixel as the background color. If the does not support transparency, then the pixels that have the same color as the bottom-left pixel will be set to the of .
member.param: The to make transparent.

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.
remarks.para: This method calls the ReplaceColor method internally.
Similarly to the Bitmap.MakeTransparent method, this one uses the bottom-left pixel to determine the background color, which must be completely opaque; otherwise, will not be changed.

Unlike the Bitmap.MakeTransparent method, this one preserves the original . If does not support transparency and cannot set either, then every occurrence of the color of the bottom-left pixel will be changed to the of . To make such bitmaps transparent use the ToTransparent method instead, which returns a new instance with .
To force replacing even non-completely opaque pixels use the overload instead.
remarks.note: Please note that unlike the MakeOpaque method, this one changes exactly one color shade without any tolerance. For any customization use the TransformColors method instead.

remarks.para: This method calls the TransformColors method internally. See the Remarks section of the TransformColors method for more details.

If has an indexed and is , then its palette entries are tried to be transformed instead of the actual pixels in the first place (if it is supported by ). The is ignored for s with more than 16 bits-per-pixel and for grayscale formats.

member.summary: Clips the specified using the specified . Unlike the Clone methods, this one returns a wrapper, providing access only to the specified region of the original .
member.param: The source bitmap data to be clipped.
A that specifies a region within the .
to dispose when the result is disposed; otherwise, .
member.returns: An that provides access only to the specified region withing the .
member.exception: is .
has no overlapping region with source bounds.

remarks.para: The property of the returned instance can be 0, indicating that the WriteRaw method cannot be used. It can occur if the left edge of the clipping is not zero.

Even if property of the returned instance is a nonzero value it can happen that it is too low to access all columns by the WriteRaw method. It can occur with indexed s if the right edge of the clipping is not on byte boundary.

member.summary: Clears the content of the specified and fills it with the specified .
member.param: The to be cleared.

A that represents the desired result color of the . If it has transparency, which is not supported by of , then the result might be either completely transparent (depends also on ), or the color will be blended with .

The ditherer to be used for the clearing. Has no effect if of has at least 24 bits-per-pixel size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overload to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginClear or ClearAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

, if the operation completed successfully.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataExtensions.Clear(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IWritableBitmapData,KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncContext,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IDitherer)
member.summary: Clears the content of the specified and fills it with the specified , using a that may belong to a higher level, possibly asynchronous operation.
member.param: The to be cleared.
An IAsyncContext instance that contains information for asynchronous processing about the current operation.

A that represents the desired result color of the . If it has transparency, which is not supported by of , then the result might be either completely transparent (depends also on ), or the color will be blended with .

The ditherer to be used for the clearing. Has no effect if of has at least 24 bits-per-pixel size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns:
, if the operation completed successfully.
, if the operation has been canceled.

remarks.para: This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorExtensions.GetBrightness(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32)
member.summary: Gets the brightness of a instance as a byte based on human perception. The component of the specified value is ignored.
member.param: The instance to get the brightness of.
member.returns: A byte value where 0 represents the darkest and 255 represents the brightest possible value.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorExtensions.GetBrightness(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.WorkingColorSpace)
member.summary: Gets the brightness of a instance as a byte based on human perception. The component of the specified value is ignored.
member.param: The instance to get the brightness of.

The color space to be used for determining the brightness. If , then the sRGB color space will be used. For performance reasons this method does not validate this parameter. For undefined values the sRGB color space will be used as well.
member.returns: A byte value where 0 represents the darkest and 255 represents the brightest possible value.

remarks.note: This method always returns a gamma corrected result, even if is . To get the brightness in the linear color space use the method instead.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorExtensions.GetBrightness(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color64)
member.summary: Gets the brightness of a instance as a based on human perception. The component of the specified value is ignored.
member.param: The instance to get the brightness of.
member.returns: A value where 0 represents the darkest and 65535 represents the brightest possible value.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorExtensions.GetBrightness(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorF)
member.summary: Gets the brightness of a instance as a float value in the linear color space. The component of the specified value is ignored.
member.param: The instance to get the brightness of.
member.returns: A float value where 0 represents the darkest and 1 represents the brightest possible value.

remarks.note: The result of this method is not gamma corrected. To get a gamma corrected float result, call the ColorSpaceHelper.LinearToSrgb method on the result, or use the GetBrightnessF methods instead.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorExtensions.TolerantEquals(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: Gets whether two instances are equal using a specified .
member.param: The first color to compare.
The second color to compare.
The allowed tolerance for ARGB components.

Specifies a threshold under which colors are considered transparent. If both colors have lower value than the threshold, then they are considered equal. If only one of the specified colors has lower value than the threshold, then the colors are considered different. If both colors' value are equal to or greater than this value, then is applied to the value, too. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 0.
member.returns: , if the colors are considered equal with the specified ; otherwise, .

member.summary: Gets whether two instances are equal using a specified .
member.param: The first color to compare.

The allowed tolerance for ARGB components.

Specifies a threshold under which colors are considered transparent. If both colors have lower value than the threshold, then they are considered equal. If only one of the specified colors has lower value than the threshold, then the colors are considered different. If both colors' value are equal to or greater than this value, then is applied to the value, too. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 0.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData
member.summary:
Represents the raw data of a bitmap. To create a managed instance use the class. To obtain a readable or writable instance for platform specific bitmaps you can either use the specific GetReadableBitmapData, GetWritableBitmapData or GetReadWriteBitmapData extension methods when applicable (see the Remarks section of the namespace for a list about the supported platforms). Otherwise, you can use the members of the class to create a bitmap data for any managed or unmanaged preallocated buffer of any bitmap implementation.
See the Remarks section of the BitmapExtensions.GetReadWriteBitmapData method for details and code samples. That method is for the GDI+ Bitmap type but the main principles apply for all sources.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.Height
member.summary: Gets the height of the current instance in pixels.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.Width
member.summary: Gets the width of the current instance in pixels.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.Size
member.summary: Gets the size of the current instance in pixels.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.PixelFormat
member.summary: Gets a of the current instance.

remarks.para: The value of this property determines how the raw underlying values should be interpreted if the pixels are accessed by the ReadRaw or WriteRaw methods. Otherwise, in most cases using the members of the interfaces derived from the and interfaces work seamlessly.
If this property returns an indexed format (see ), then the property returns a non- value.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.Palette
member.summary: Gets a instance representing the colors used in this if represents an indexed format. For indexed bitmaps property of returns .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.RowSize
member.summary: Gets the size of a row in bytes, or zero, if this instance does not have an actual raw buffer to access.

remarks.para: This property can be useful when accessing the bitmap data by the ReadRaw or WriteRaw methods.
As can represent any custom bitmap data, row size is not guaranteed to be a multiple of 4.

note.para: This property can return 0 if the current instance represents a bitmap data without actual raw data or represents a clipped region where the left edge of the clipping has an offset compared to the original bitmap data.

Even if this property returns a nonzero value, it is possible that raw access does not cover the few last columns. This may occur in case of indexed s if the bitmap data is clipped and the right edge of the clipping does not fall at byte boundary.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.BackColor
member.summary:
When accessing pixels of indexed bitmaps, or setting pixels of bitmaps without alpha support, gets the color of the background. For example, when setting color values with alpha, which are considered opaque, they will be blended with this color before setting the pixel.
See the Remarks section of the GetReadWriteBitmapData extension method for details and examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.AlphaThreshold
member.summary: If this represents a bitmap with single bit alpha or with a palette that has a transparent color, then gets a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which the color is considered transparent. If 0, then the pixels to be set will never be transparent.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.WorkingColorSpace
member.summary:
Gets the preferred working color space when dealing with the pixels of this instance. Some operations, such as setting pixels or drawing another bitmap data into this instance consider the value of this property. Operations that use an instance may override the value of this property.
Default value if not implemented: . (Only in .NET Core 3.0/.NET Standard 2.1 and above. In earlier targeted frameworks this member must be implemented.)

remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the enumeration for details and image examples about using the different color spaces in various operations.
remarks.para: For implementations the property primarily determines how to blend colors in drawing operations or when this does not support transparency and partially transparent colors are set by the or members. Custom implementations may ignore the value of this property. Some other operations such as cloning, resizing, etc. may also respect the value of this property.

When is , the working color space is chosen based on the context. For example, when setting a pixel using the type, the sRGB blending will be picked (unless has the flag enabled) because it is faster, and it is the default behavior for most applications.
For some operations, such as drawing a bitmap data into another one by the DrawInto methods the working color space is determined by the of the target bitmap data.

When using a quantizer for some operations, it may override the value of this property. As quantizers are limited to the 32 bit ARGB color space, the built-in implementations in this library also use sRGB blending by default but you can override it by the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.ConfigureColorSpace and OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.ConfigureColorSpace methods.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.IsDisposed

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IDitherer
member.summary:
Represents a ditherer that can be used to dither the result of a quantizing session.
For built-in implementations see the , , and classes.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IDitherer.InitializeReliesOnContent
member.summary: Gets whether Initialize relies on the actual content of the source to be dithered.

remarks.para: This property should return , if Initialize method relies on the exact content to be dithered in order to make the GetDitheredColor method work properly.

If this property returns , then Initialize will be called with an instance, whose and properties can be used but the actual content might be different from the one will be used when calling the GetDitheredColor method.

The return value of this property may affect the performance of some drawing operations where returning forces the source and target images to be blended together before dithering the result, while returning allows the ditherer to be initialized with the source image and let the GetDitheredColor method to be called with colors that are blended on-the-fly during the dithering.

member.summary: Gets whether this ditherer allows only sequential processing (line by line). Even returning does not guarantee that every pixel will be queried. It just enforces that queried rows are processed sequentially.
member.value: If , then the GetDitheredColor method will be called sequentially for each queried pixels. If , then the GetDitheredColor method can be called concurrently for any pixels.

Represents a quantizer that can be used to reduce the number of colors of an image.
For built-in implementations see the and classes.

member.summary: Gets a that is compatible with this . It is recommended to return the format with the lowest bits-per-pixel value that is still compatible with this instance.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizer.InitializeReliesOnContent
member.summary: Gets whether Initialize relies on the actual content of the source to be quantized.

remarks.para: This property should return , if Initialize method relies on the exact content to be quantized in order to generate a palette and make the GetQuantizedColor method work properly.

If this property returns , then Initialize will be called with an instance, whose and properties can be used but the actual content might be different from the one will be used when calling the GetQuantizedColor method.

The return value of this property may affect the performance of some drawing operations where returning forces the source and target images to be blended together before quantizing the result, while returning allows the quantizer to be initialized with the source image and let the GetQuantizedColor method to be called with colors that are blended on-the-fly during the quantization.

Contains information for asynchronous processing about the current operation. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An instance that can be used to quantize the colors of the specified instance.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession
member.summary: Represents a disposable quantizing session returned by the IQuantizer.Initialize method that is used to quantize (reduce the colors) of a specific source.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.Palette
member.summary: Gets the palette containing the colors of the quantized result. Expected to be called if the target of the quantization is indexed. Typical indexed pixel formats contain no more than 256 colors; however, it is allowed to return a bigger . If the corresponding returns a non-indexed pixel format in its property, then this property can return .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.BackColor
member.summary:
Gets the background color for this . When the GetQuantizedColor is called with a color with alpha, which is considered opaque, then it will be blended with this color before quantizing.
See also the Remarks section of the property for details.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.AlphaThreshold
member.summary: If this can produce transparent pixels, then gets the alpha threshold value that can be used to determine whether a color with alpha should be considered transparent or should be blended with .

remarks.para: If this can produce transparent pixels, and GetQuantizedColor is called with a color, whose Color32.A field is lower than the threshold, then the returned color will be transparent.

If this cannot produce transparent pixels, or GetQuantizedColor is called with a color, whose Color32.A field is greater than or equal to the threshold, then the returned color will be will be blended with before quantizing.
If is 0, then the quantized color will never be transparent.
If is 255, then only fully opaque colors will not be considered transparent.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.IsGrayscale
member.summary:
Gets whether this works with grayscale colors. Its value may help to optimize the processing in some cases but it is allowed to return always .
Default value if not implemented: . (Only in .NET Core 3.0/.NET Standard 2.1 and above. In earlier targeted frameworks this member must be implemented.)

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.WorkingColorSpace
member.summary:
Gets the preferred working color space of this instance. If this quantizing session is used by a ditherer, then implementations may also respect the value of this property.
Default value if not implemented: . (Only in .NET Core 3.0/.NET Standard 2.1 and above. In earlier targeted frameworks this member must be implemented.)

remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the enumeration for details and image examples about using the different color spaces in various operations.

Gets the quantized color of the specified . If property has non- return value, then the result color must be a valid entry.
See also the Remarks section of the property for details.
member.param: The original color to be quantized.
member.returns: The quantized color.

Line by line processing is also possible by obtaining the first row by the property, getting the pixels by the members and then moving to the next line by the MoveNextRow method.
To access the actual -dependent raw value you can use the ReadRaw method.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadWriteBitmapData
member.summary:
Represents an instance with read/write access. To create an instance use the class or the GetReadWriteBitmapData extension methods for various platform dependent bitmap implementations.
See the Remarks section of the namespace for a list about the technologies with dedicated support.
See the Remarks section of the BitmapExtensions.GetReadWriteBitmapData method for details and code samples. That method is for the GDI+ Bitmap type but the main principles apply for all sources.

member.summary: Gets or sets the color of the pixel in the current row at the specified coordinate.
member.param: The x-coordinate of the pixel to set.
member.value: A instance that represents the color of the specified pixel.

remarks.para: To return a structure you can use also the GetColor method but this member has a slightly better performance.
To set the color from a structure you can use also the SetColor method but this member has a slightly better performance.

The color value represents a straight (non-premultiplied) color with gamma correction γ = 2.2, regardless of the underlying . To access the actual -dependent raw data use the ReadRaw and WriteRaw methods.
If the color to be set is not supported by owner , then it will be quantized to a supported color value.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the GetReadWriteBitmapData method for examples.

member.summary: Sets the color of the pixel at the specified coordinates from a value.
member.param: The x-coordinate of the pixel to set.
The y-coordinate of the pixel to set.
A value that represents the color to assign to the specified pixel.

remarks.para: The parameter represents a non-premultiplied color with 8 bits per channel in the sRGB color space, regardless of the underlying . The SetColor32 method works with the same range of colors as this one and has a slightly better performance.
Line by line processing is also possible by obtaining the first row by the property, setting the pixels by the members and then moving to the next line by the MoveNextRow method.
To access the actual -dependent raw value obtain a row and use the WriteRaw method.
If the color to be set cannot be represented precisely by the owner , then it will be quantized to a supported color value.

member.summary: Sets the color of the pixel in the current row at the specified coordinate from a value.
member.param: The x-coordinate of the pixel to set.
member.value: A instance that represents the color of the specified pixel.

remarks.para: The represents a non-premultiplied color with 8 bits per channel in the sRGB color space, regardless of the underlying . This member is practically the same as the SetColor32 method.
To access the actual -dependent raw value use the WriteRaw method.
If the color to be set cannot be represented precisely by the owner , then it will be quantized to a supported color value.
