member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer
member.summary:
Represents a quantizer that can generate an optimized set of colors best matching to the original image. Use the static methods to retrieve an instance. For using predefined colors see the class.
See the online help for image examples.

remarks.para: The class can be used to reduce colors of an using a palette of up to 65536 colors where the palette entries are optimized for the quantized image. Though more than 256 colors are supported, the typical goal of palette optimization is to adjust the colors for an indexed pixel format. Natively supported indexed formats cannot have more than 256 colors, though you are allowed to create images with a custom pixel format by using the BitmapDataFactory.CreateBitmapData methods that have or parameters. Please note though that a large palette may have impact on both memory usage and performance.
This class supports palette optimization by three different algorithms (see the Octree, MedianCut and Wu methods)

example.para:
The following table compares the algorithms supported by the class:
OctreeMedianCutWu
Speed With default settings usually slower than the Wu's algorithm and has a similar speed as MedianCut. When using high bit levels and the source is a true color image, then it is generally faster for high requested colors, and can be faster even than Wu's algorithm using the same bit level. When using a low bit level or just a few colors, this one is the slowest one of the three algorithms, especially for larger images. When producing 256 or more colors its speed is similar to the Octree algorithm. With default settings this is almost always the fastest one of the three algorithms (still much slower though than the quantizers of the class). When using high bit levels it can be the slowest one for small images and gets to be the fastest one for larger image sizes.
Memory consumption* Generating the palette may consume quite a large amount of memory, but it also depends on the number of different colors of the source image and the requested color count. The memory is continuously allocated on demand and in extreme cases it may consume a huge amount of memory. The memory usage can be limited by the ConfigureBitLevel method. The memory usage mainly depends on the image size and somewhat on the requested color count. Quantizing a large image may consume a large amount of memory even if the image itself consist of just a few colors. It uses array pooling on platforms that support it. This quantizer consumes a fairly large fix amount of memory, even if the source has few colors and the requested color count is small. Most of the memory is allocated at once, regardless of the image size or its actual colors, and a smaller portion is allocated dynamically, which depends on the number of requested colors. On platforms where available, array pooling is used, which releases the used memory only after a while if the buffers are not re-used within a time interval. The memory usage can be adjusted by the ConfigureBitLevel method.
Quality
Usually poorer quality for smaller palettes (below 16 colors).
Banding may appear in images with large low-frequency areas (e.g. sky or water in photos).
Balanced quality for larger palettes and photo-like images.
Usually better quality for smaller palettes.t
Excellent, nearly banding-free results with images with large low-frequency areas (e.g. sky or water in photos).
May provide poorer quality for small areas with unique colors (e.g. a smaller human face in a large photo).
Usually very good quality even for smaller palettes.
Banding may appear in images with large low-frequency areas (e.g. sky or water in photos). By default, banding may appear for monochromatic images even if the requested number of colors would allow a banding-free result but this can be configured by the ConfigureBitLevel method.
Very good quality for photo-like images, especially if the image has no homogeneous low-frequency areas.
*Memory consumption mentioned in the table affects palette generation only. That occurs when the IQuantizer.Initialize method of an instance is called. As soon as this method returns with an instance, the memory mentioned in the table can be reclaimed (which does not necessarily happen immediately on platforms that support array pooling, which is utilized by the MedianCut and Wu algorithms).
On the other hand, the can also consume a large amount of memory during the quantization because its caches the quantization results of the source image pixels, though this caching does not depend on the chosen algorithm and the used memory can also be reclaimed when the is disposed.
Keeping a reference to an consumes almost no memory when there is no active quantization session in progress.

The following table compares the results of the instances returned by the Octree, MedianCut and Wu methods. For better comparison none of the images are dithered in the examples, though the visual quality can be improved by using dithering. See the , , and classes for some built-in implementations.
Original image
Quantized image
Color hues with alpha gradient
Octree algorithm, 256 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
MedianCut algorithm, 256 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Wu's algorithm, 256 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Information icon with transparency
Octree algorithm, 4 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
MedianCut algorithm, 4 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Wu's algorithm, 4 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Octree algorithm, 256 colors, black background, alpha threshold = 128. Banding appeared in the result.
MedianCut algorithm, 256 colors, black background, alpha threshold = 128. Practically there is no banding in the result.
Wu's algorithm, 256 colors, black background, alpha threshold = 128. A slight banding can be observed, as if the source image had been prequantized by the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Argb1555 quantizer first. You get this result if you use the ConfigureBitLevel method with 5 bits (which is the default for Wu with 256 colors). The banding can be reduced by using higher bit levels, which increases also memory usage and processing time.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.ConfigureBitLevel(System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Configures the bit level per color channel to be used while optimizing the palette. If the input image is a monochromatic one, then may determine the bit depth of the result, depending on the used algorithm. Affects the quality, speed and memory usage.
member.param: Specifies the desired bit level. If , then the value is automatically set by the chosen algorithm.
member.returns: An instance that has the specified bit level.
member.exception: must be either , or between 1 and 8.

remarks.para: As a primary effect, determines the upper limit of the possible colors in the generated palette. For example, if is 1, then the result palette will not have more than 8 colors, or when it is 2, more than 64 colors. If you want to quantize an image using the allowed maximum of 65536 colors, then should be at least 6 because 5 allows up to 32768 colors.

When using the MedianCut algorithm, configuring the bit level has no other effects. When using the Octree or Wu's algorithms, determines also the amount of minimum distinguishable monochromatic shades. For example, when is 5, then up to 32 monochromatic shades can be differentiated so close shades might be merged even if the requested number of colors would allow returning all the shades.

For the Octree algorithm the default value is the ceiling of the base 2 logarithm of the requested number of colors (e.g. 1 for 2 colors, 8 for 129 or more colors). This is alright for most cases. You can increase the default value if the image has only a few but very close colors or decrease it if the image has so many colors that the quantization would use too much memory.

For Wu's algorithm the default value is 5 for no more than 256 colors (requires about 1.5 MB fix memory) and 6 for more colors (requires about 10 MB). This provides good enough quality in most cases but may cause visible banding if the input image is monochrome. To avoid that you can increase the bit level, which dramatically increases also the memory requirement: 7 bits requires about 80 MB memory, whereas 8 bits demands about 650 MB, regardless of the actual number of colors in the source image.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer
member.summary: Credit to Xiaolin Wu's Color Quantizer published at https://www.ece.mcmaster.ca/~xwu/cq.c This quantizer is mainly based on his code.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.CubicBuffer`1
member.summary: Similar to (it allows both 3D and 1D access) but allows negative indices, which returns default value. The original algorithm uses 33x33x33 arrays, where 0 indices are never set in any dimensions so they were always 0. This was acceptable for the original algorithm but with 8 bit resolution (257x257x257 * sizeof(T)) the waste is much more significant, especially with array pooling, which allocates almost twice as much memory as needed when dimensions are 2^n + 1.

member.summary: Computes the sum over a box of any given statistic (floating point version).

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.sqrTable
member.summary: Just a lookup table for squared values between 0..255

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.m2
member.summary: The squared moment values of color RGB values. After building the histogram by an element of this array can be interpreted as m2[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of c^2*P(c) and after it contains cumulative moments. The strictly taken Bernoulli probability is actually multiplied by image size. In Wu's original algorithm effective histogram elements were in 1.. along each axis, element 0 was just for base or marginal value. Here values are zero-based, but reading -1 index is allowed, which returns zero. Values are floats just because of the possible big ranges due to squared values.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.wt
member.summary: The counts of voxels of the 3D color cubes in each position. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of P(c)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.mr
member.summary: The moment values of red color components. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of r*P(c)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.mg
member.summary: The moment values of green color components. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of g*P(c)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.mb
member.summary: The moment values of green color components. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of b*P(c)

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.HistogramToMoments(KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncContext)
member.summary: Computing cumulative moments from the histogram.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.Var(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.Box)
member.summary: Compute the weighted variance of a box. Note: as with the raw statistics, this is actually the variance multiplied by image size

member.summary:
Represents a quantizer with predefined set of colors. Use the static members to retrieve an instance. For using optimized colors for a specific source image see the class.
See the Remarks section of the static methods of this class for details and image examples.

member.summary:

See the Remarks section of the IQuantizingSession.AlphaThreshold property for details.

member.summary:

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Palette
P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PredefinedColorsQuantizer.WorkingColorSpace
member.summary: Gets the preferred color space of this instance for quantizing. This value will be returned also by the property once an is created from this instance. You can use the ConfigureColorSpace method to create a clone of this using a different working color space.

remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the enumeration for details and image examples about using the different color spaces in various operations.
remarks.para: If the value of this property is , then the sRGB color space is used because the IQuantizingSession.GetQuantizedColor method works with sRGB colors anyway.

If this instance uses a custom quantizing functions, then it depends on the function whether it considers the value of this property. When using a high color quantizer, then the value of this property may only affect possible alpha blending with the property.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Argb8888(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte)
member.summary:
Gets a instance that can quantize colors to the 32-bit ARGB color space.
See the online help for an example with images.
member.param:
Determines the property of the returned quantizer. Considering that this quantizer can return alpha colors it has effect only when the returned quantizer is used with a ditherer that does not support partial transparency. The Color32.A field of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value:The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as Color.Black.

Specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which a quantized color is considered completely transparent. If 0, then the quantized colors will preserve their original alpha value. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: A instance that can quantize colors to the 32-bit ARGB color space.

remarks.para: If is zero, then the returned instance is practically just a pass-through filter in the 32-bit color space, and it is effective only for some bitmap data operations (eg. Clone), which could possibly preserve wide color information (s with more than 32 bpp) without specifying a quantizer.
If is not zero, then every partially transparent pixel with lower Color.A value than the threshold will turn completely transparent.
This quantizer fits well for the pixel format.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Rgb888(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte)
member.summary:
Gets a instance that can quantize colors to 24-bit ones where each color component is encoded in 8 bits.
See the online help for an example with images.
member.param:
Colors with alpha (transparency) will be blended with this color before quantizing. The Color32.A field of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as Color.Black.

Specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which a quantized color is considered completely transparent. Though the quantizer returned from this method never returns alpha colors, it can be relevant in some cases, for example when drawing a partially transparent bitmap onto a solid background. The source pixels, whose alpha value is below the will be skipped, whereas alpha pixels with higher opacity will be blended with the specified . This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: A instance that can quantize colors to 24-bit ones where each color component is encoded in 8 bits.

remarks.para: The returned instance can return up to 2563 (16,777,216) colors. It practically just removes transparency and does not change colors without alpha.
This quantizer fits well for the pixel format.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Rgb565(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte)
member.summary:
Gets a instance that can quantize colors to 16-bit ones where red, green and blue components are encoded in 5, 6 and 5 bits, respectively.
See the online help for an example with images.

Colors with alpha (transparency) will be blended with this color before quantizing. The Color32.A field of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.

to map any color directly to an index instead of searching for a nearest color, which is very fast but without dithering may end up in a noticeably poorer result and higher contrast; to perform a lookup to determine nearest colors, which may be slower but more accurate. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

Specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which a quantized color is considered completely transparent. Though the quantizer returned from this method never returns alpha colors, it can be relevant in some cases, for example when drawing a partially transparent bitmap onto a solid background. The source pixels, whose alpha value is below the will be skipped, whereas alpha pixels with higher opacity will be blended with the specified . This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: A instance that can quantize colors to 8-bit ones where red, green and blue components are encoded in 3, 3 and 2 bits, respectively.

remarks.para: If is , then the result of the quantizing may have a higher contrast than without direct color mapping, though this can be compensated if the returned quantizer is combined with an . Other ditherers preserve the effect of the parameter.
The returned instance can return up to 256 colors.
This quantizer fits well for the pixel format.
The palette of this quantizer does not contain the transparent color.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Grayscale(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte)
member.summary:

member.param:
Colors with alpha (transparency) will be blended with this color before quantizing. The Color32.A field of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.

Though the quantizer returned from this method never returns alpha colors, it can be relevant in some cases, for example when drawing a partially transparent bitmap onto a solid background. The source pixels, whose alpha value is below the will be skipped, whereas alpha pixels with higher opacity will be blended with the specified . This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: A instance that can quantize colors to 8-bit grayscale ones.

remarks.para: The returned quantizer uses direct mapping to grayscale colors based on human perception, which makes quantizing very fast while it is very accurate at the same time.
The returned instance can return up to 256 possible shades of gray.
The palette of this quantizer does not contain the transparent color. To make a bitmap data grayscale with transparency you can use the ToGrayscale and MakeGrayscale extension methods.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PredefinedColorsQuantizer.FromCustomPalette(System.Drawing.Color[],System.Drawing.Color,System.Byte)
member.summary: Gets a instance that can quantize colors using the colors in the specified .
member.param: The array of colors to be used by the returned instance.

Colors with alpha (transparency), which are considered opaque will be blended with this color before quantizing. The Color.A property of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: , which has the same RGB values as .

If the specified contains a transparent color, then specifies a threshold value for the Color.A property, under which a quantized color is considered transparent. If 0, then the quantized colors will never be transparent. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.note: For examples see the Examples section of the overload.
member.returns: A instance that can quantize colors using the colors in the specified .

remarks.para: The instance returned by this method will use a internally, created from the colors specified in the parameter. When quantizing, best matching colors might be looked up sequentially and results might be cached.
If a color to be quantized can be mapped to a color index directly, then create a instance explicitly, specifying the custom mapping logic and use the overload instead.
If a color to be quantized can be transformed to a result color directly, and the quantized result is not needed to be an indexed image, then use the FromCustomFunction overloads instead.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PredefinedColorsQuantizer.FromCustomFunction(System.Func{KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32},KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.KnownPixelFormat,System.Byte)
member.summary:
Gets a instance that can quantize colors using the custom quantizer function specified in the parameter.
See the online help for an example with images.
member.param: A delegate that specifies the custom quantizing logic. It must be thread-safe for parallel invoking, and it is expected to be fast. The results returned by the delegate are not cached.
Colors with alpha (transparency), which are considered opaque will be blended with this color before invoking the delegate. The Color32.A field of the background color is ignored.

The value that the property of the returned instance will return. This parameter is optional.
Default value: , which is valid only if has the default zero value.

Specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which a quantized color is considered transparent. If 0, then even the completely transparent colors will be blended with before invoking the delegate. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 0.
member.returns: A instance that can quantize colors using the custom quantizer function specified in the parameter.

remarks.para: The quantizer returned by this method does not have a palette. If you need to create an indexed result using a custom mapping function that uses up to 256 different colors, then create a instance specifying a custom function and call the method instead.

This overload never calls the delegate with a color with alpha. Depending on either a completely transparent color will be returned or the color will be blended with before invoking the delegate. In order to allow invoking with alpha colors use the or overloads instead.

This overload always calls the delegate without preprocessing the input colors. In order to pass only opaque colors to the delegate use the overload instead.

This overload always creates a quantizer with black and zero . member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo
member.summary: Represents a pixel format in a technology-agnostic way. Can be used to specify custom pixel formats for the CreateBitmapData method overloads with a , or parameter.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.BitsPerPixel
member.summary: Gets or sets the bits per pixel value of this . Supported range is 1..128 (or 1..16 for formats). Typical values are powers of two but any value is supported.
member.exception: When setting this property, must be between 1 and 128.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.HasAlpha
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format has an alpha channel (transparency). For formats this property can be because alpha support is determined by the current palette. Setting this property to resets also the and properties.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.Indexed
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format is an indexed one. An indexed format is not expected to have more than 16 (up to 65536 color entries).
member.value:
If , then pixel data represent entries instead of direct colors.
If , then pixel data represent specific colors.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.Grayscale
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format is a grayscale one. For formats this property can be because grayscale nature is determined by the current palette. Setting this property for non-indexed custom grayscale formats helps to auto select the preferable strategy for some operations such as dithering.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.HasPremultipliedAlpha
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format uses premultiplied alpha. Setting this property to sets also the property.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.HasSingleBitAlpha
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format supports single-bit alpha only (a pixel is either completely transparent or completely opaque). Setting this property to sets also the property. It is not mandatory to set this property for custom single-bit alpha formats but it helps optimizing some drawing operations.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.LinearGamma
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format has linear gamma. For formats this property should be because it can be configured at the constructors and factory methods whether the palette should work in the linear color space. If the IBitmapData.WorkingColorSpace property returns , then the value of this property may affect the selected color space of some operations.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.Prefers64BitColors
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format prefers 64-bit colors (, or if is also set) when getting or setting pixels. Some operations may consider the value of this property. Setting this property to resets the property. If is also set, then some writing operations may prefer using or types regardless of this property.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.Prefers128BitColors
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format prefers 128-bit colors (, or if is also set) when getting or setting pixels. Some operations may consider the value of this property. Setting this property to resets the property.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.IsCustomFormat
member.summary: Gets whether the represented pixel format is a custom one. That is, when this was not instantiated by its constructor with a parameter or one of its properties have been set since then.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
The namespace provides advanced imaging functionality such as low-level bitmap data access for any pixel format, interfaces for quantization and dithering along with some built-in implementations, etc.
See the Remarks section of the namespace for details about the available KGy SOFT Drawing packages and their covered namespaces.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.ArcSegment.DrawAsLinesThreshold
member.summary: The maximum diameter for Bresenham ellipse drawing. Above this threshold, it's faster to draw the ellipse as flattened Bézier curves. Also, as lines, no overflow will occur for big radii.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Brush
member.summary:
Represents a brush for shape filling operations. Use the static Create... methods to create an instance.
See the online help for image examples.

remarks.para: Brushes are used for filling shapes. There are several shape-filling methods in the class, whose names start with Fill or BeginFill. The ones that have no parameter use a solid brush implicitly, created from the specified instance.
The class is abstract, and you can create instances by using the static Create... methods. The created instances are immutable.
remarks.note: In fact, even a uses a internally for drawing the outlines of shapes. You can use the appropriate constructor, or the property to set a brush for a .

example.para:
The following table enlists the available brushes and their factory methods:
DescriptionImage Example
CreateSolid: Creates a solid brush with a single color. , and overloads are available, and you can also use the named members to cast them to implicitly. For example, Brush.CreateSolid(Color32.FromArgb(128, Color.Blue)) creates a blue solid brush with 50% transparency that can produce a similar result to the one in the image.
CreateLinearGradient: Creates a linear gradient brush. There are two groups of overloads: one for specifying a pair of start/end points optionally with some , and another one with an angle, which automatically stretches the gradient for the paths to fill.
The top image uses specific start/end points without repeating the gradient, whereas the bottom one just specified a zero angle to create a horizontal gradient. Note that in the bottom image the start/end points are automatically adjusted to the bounds of the shape in each fill sessions. Both examples filled a single elliptic path with three different translations.
See the Examples section of the enumeration and the method for more image examples.
CreateTexture: Creates a texture brush. A can be specified, which allows tiling, stretching, centering and a few other modes.
The top image uses a texture with a map mode of tiling with mirroring on both axes, whereas the bottom one centers the same texture and uses no alpha blending, so where there is no texture pixel to set, the path region cuts a transparent hole in the image. Both examples filled a single elliptic path with three different translations.
See the Examples section of the enumeration for more image examples.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Brush.PathSessionBase.FinalizeSession
member.summary: Completing the session if it wasn't canceled and there were no errors. Unlike Dispose, this executes only on success.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Brush.SolidRegionScanner.SolidScannerContext
member.summary: Contains thread-specific data for region scanning

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Brush.AntiAliasingRegionScanner.AntiAliasingScannerContext
member.summary: Contains thread-specific data for region scanning

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Brush.ActiveEdgeTableNonZero.sortStabilizerDelta
member.summary: A constant, that is smaller than snapping factor for subpixel size, used to prevent sorting from mixing up elements with the same key. Its value is smaller than subpixel snapping distance (actually the same as equality tolerance for interpolated resizing).

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Brush.EdgeInfo
member.summary: Represents an edge during the traversal of the raw vertices. The fields can be mutated during processing.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Brush.EdgeEntry
member.summary: Represents an entry in the global edge table. Unlike , this struct is not mutable. The basic idea is taken from here: https://www.cs.rit.edu/~icss571/filling/how_to.html The slope of the edge can be defined as y = mx + b, where m is the slope and b = y - intercept. From this, the reciprocal slope can be defined as x = py + q where p and q are analogue to m and b.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Brush.CreateSolid(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32)
member.summary:
Creates a solid with the specified 32-bit color.
See the online help for an image example.

remarks.para: If the has alpha and DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending is , the color space used for blending is determined by the specified , or, when it is , by the of the target .

member.summary:

Determines how the texture is mapped to the target area. This parameter is optional.

to indicate that the uses the alpha channel (has transparency); otherwise, . This parameter is optional.

remarks.para: This overload maps the entire to the target . To use only a smaller region of it, use the overload instead.

If the pixel format of the has alpha channel, but the does not use it, you can set the parameter to to improve performance. If the pixel format of the does not have an alpha channel, then this parameter is ignored.

If the pixel format of the has alpha channel, but the does not use it, you can set the parameter to to improve performance. If the pixel format of the does not have an alpha channel, then this parameter is ignored.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Brush.CreateLinearGradient(System.Drawing.PointF,System.Drawing.PointF,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.GradientWrapMode,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.WorkingColorSpace)
member.summary:
Creates a linear gradient that blends from one color to another along a straight line specified by and .
See the Examples section of the enumeration for image examples.
member.param: The starting point of the gradient.
The end point of the gradient.
The starting color of the gradient.
The end color of the gradient.

Determines how the gradient is treated outside the gradient area. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

Determines the color space in which the gradient is calculated. This parameter is optional.
Default value: , which means for this overload.
member.returns: A linear gradient that uses the specified parameters.

remarks.para: This overload creates a gradient with fix coordinates. To automatically apply the gradient to the bounds of each , use the overloads with an angle parameter, such as the overload.

The parameter affects only the color interpolation, not the blending with the background, which is determined by the color space of the target bitmap data (or by DrawingOptions.Quantizer, if specified).

In this overload the default value of maps to WorkingColorSpace.Srgb, because the type represents a color in the sRGB color space. When creating a monochromatic gradient, specifying can be better, because then the perceived mid-tone brightness will be at the middle of the gradient. Otherwise, using may be more appropriate, so the transition between the colors will seem more "natural".

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Brush.CreateLinearGradient(System.Single,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.WorkingColorSpace)
member.summary:
Creates a linear gradient that blends from one color to another along a straight line. The line is specified by an only, whereas the actual start and end points are determined by the bounding rectangle of the current in each session.
See the online help for an example with image.
member.param: The angle of the gradient line in degrees. The angle is measured clockwise from the positive x-axis.
The starting color of the gradient.
The end color of the gradient.

Determines the color space in which the gradient is calculated. This parameter is optional.
Default value: , which means for this overload.
member.returns: A linear gradient that uses the specified parameters.

remarks.para: This overload creates a gradient with dynamic coordinates, applying the gradient automatically to the bounds of each . To use fix coordinates instead, use the overloads with a startPoint and endPoint parameters, such as the overload.

The parameter affects only the color interpolation, not the blending with the background, which is determined by the color space of the target bitmap data (or by DrawingOptions.Quantizer, if specified).

In this overload the default value of maps to WorkingColorSpace.Srgb, because the type represents a color in the sRGB color space. When creating a monochromatic gradient, specifying can be better, because then the perceived mid-tone brightness will be at the middle of the gradient. Otherwise, using may be more appropriate, so the transition between the colors will seem more "natural".

example.para: The example above produces the result below. Note that the gradient always starts from the left edge of the ellipse and ends at the right edge, regardless of the ellipse's location. As a contrast, see the examples at the enumeration, where the gradients always use specific start and end points.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DirectDrawer
member.summary: This class is used to draw thin paths and to fill rectangles with solid colors. These drawing algorithms are actually duplicated in the classes derived from DrawThinPathSession in . These are used in special cases, and are optimized for performance. See also the comments in for more info.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions
member.summary: Provides options for drawing and filling shapes. See the description of the properties for details and examples. The default options (which is also used when is passed to the drawing methods) uses alpha blending but no anti-aliasing, and uses fast shape-filling and thin path drawing strategies.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions.Transformation
member.summary:
Gets or sets the transformation matrix to apply when drawing shapes.
Default value: TransformationMatrix.Identity.
See the online help for an example with image.

remarks.para: This property allows applying transformations (e.g. translation, rotation, zoom, etc.) when drawing shapes. It can be particularly useful when drawing shapes directly, without creating a instance. For example, the DrawEllipse methods don't offer a parameter for rotation.

Setting this property to a value other than the identity matrix disables path region caching for instances, even if Path.PreferCaching is . To achieve the best performance when drawing the same shape with the same transformation multiple times, use a instance with caching enabled, apply the transformation to the , and use the identity matrix here.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions.AntiAliasing
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether anti-aliasing is enabled when drawing shapes.
Default value: .
See the online help for image examples.

remarks.para: When anti-aliasing is enabled, the shapes are drawn with smooth edges, which affects both shape filling and path drawing.
Anti-aliasing uses 16x16 subpixels per pixel to achieve smooth edges. This means that anti-aliased drawing is slower than aliased drawing.

example.para:
The following images provide a few examples regarding anti-aliasing:
DescriptionImage Example
Filling a polygon with = .
Filling a polygon with = .
Drawing a with = , = . This is the default configuration of these properties.
Drawing a with = , = , = . Note that the lines are more jagged than above.
Drawing a with = , = . The lines are much smoother.
Drawing an ellipse with = , = . The image is zoomed in for better visibility.
Drawing an ellipse with = , = , = . The image is zoomed in for better visibility.
Drawing an ellipse with = , = . The image is zoomed in for better visibility.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions.FastThinLines
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether drawing s and primitive shapes with thin lines are drawn with a faster algorithm when is .
Default value: .
See the online help for image examples.

remarks.para: When is , thin lines (that is, when Pen.Width is less or equal to 1) and arcs are drawn with a Bresenham-like algorithm, which is both faster and produces better results than the default algorithm.
This property has no effect when is .

example.para:
The following images provide a few examples:
DescriptionImage Example
Drawing a with = , = . This is the default configuration of these properties.
Drawing a with = , = , = . Note that the lines are more jagged than above.
Drawing a with = , = . The lines are much smoother.
Drawing an ellipse with = , = . The image is zoomed in for better visibility.
Drawing an ellipse with = , = , = . The image is zoomed in for better visibility.

Though enabling usually produces better results, sometimes it still may be beneficial to disable it. For example, when filling and drawing the same without anti-aliasing, in some cases the 1-pixel width outline may not be perfectly aligned with the fill area, unless is disabled:
DescriptionImage Example
Filling and drawing the same polygon with = , = . You can observe alignment issues.
Filling and drawing the same polygon with = , = . Now there is no alignment issue

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether alpha blending is enabled when drawing shapes.
Default value: .
See the online help for image examples.

remarks.para: When this property is , the alpha channel of the colors is blended with the target image. The used color space for blending is the target's , or the one that the uses (if specified).
Alpha blending may be required in two cases: when the used has transparent colors, or when the property is .

If this property is , the alpha channel is written directly to the target image. This is usually not desired with anti-aliased shapes, except for already transparent background images, because it may produce alpha pixels along the edges of the shapes, even when the background is fully opaque.
When is , drawing or filling a shape with a completely transparent will not affect the target image, whereas when it is , a transparent can be used to draw transparent shapes.

example.para:
The following images provide a few examples regarding alpha blending:
DescriptionImage Example
Filling a polygon with = , = , using a solid brush with 50% transparency on an alpha gradient background. Note that no blending occurs, so the polygon is just filled with the specified alpha color.
Filling a polygon with = , = , using a solid brush with 50% transparency on an alpha gradient background. The blending uses the color space of the target , which is linear in this case.
Filling a polygon with = , using a completely transparent brush. Note that this way we can "cut" transparent "holes" into a bitmap. If the target does not support transparency, the shape will be filled with the color of the target bitmap data.
Filling a polygon with = , = . When anti-aliasing is enabled, it's not recommended to turn off alpha blending (unless the background is transparent), because it may produce alpha pixels along the edges of the shapes, even when the background is fully opaque.
Filling a polygon with = , = .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions.FillMode
member.summary:
Gets or sets the fill mode to use when filling shapes.
Default value: .
See the online help for image examples.

remarks.para: If a polygon has no self-crossing lines, then both fill modes produce the same result, in which case the default mode can be a better choice because it is faster.

example.para:
The following examples demonstrate the difference between the two fill modes:
DescriptionImage Example
= ShapeFillMode.Alternate (default): When scanning the region of a polygon to be filled, a point is considered to be the part of the polygon if the scanline crosses odd number of lines before reaching the point to be drawn, and is considered not to be the part of the polygon if the scanline crosses even number of lines. This strategy is faster than the mode, though it may produce "holes" when a polygon has self-crossing lines.
= ShapeFillMode.NonZero: It considers the direction of the path segments at each intersection, adding/subtracting one at every clockwise/counterclockwise intersection. The point is considered to be the part of the polygon if the sum is not zero.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions.ScanPathPixelOffset
member.summary:
Gets or sets the pixel offset to use for the scanlines when scanning the region of a instance.
Default value: .
See the online help for image examples.

remarks.para: When filling a instance, the region is scanned by horizontal lines (scanlines) to determine which pixels are inside the path. When the value of this property is , the scanning is performed at the top of the pixels, whereas when it is , the scanning is performed at the center of the pixels.
When is , the pixel offset refers to the subpixels, and the difference is much less noticeable.

example.para:
The following images provide a few examples:
DescriptionImage Example
= PixelOffset.None, = : When filling shapes, the scanning of edges occurs at the top of the pixels. The shape in the example has integer vertex coordinates, the top edge is descending, whereas the bottom is ascending 1 pixel from the left to the right. The example is enlarged to show the effect.
= PixelOffset.Half, = (default): The scanning of edges occurs at the center of the pixels. The shape is the same as above. The example is enlarged to show the effect.
= PixelOffset.None, = : When filling shapes, the scanning of edges occurs at the top of the subpixels. When anti-aliasing is enabled, makes a much less noticeable difference, though the gradients of the top and bottom lines are a bit different. The example is enlarged to show the effect.
= PixelOffset.Half, = : The scanning of edges occurs at the center of the subpixels. The result is almost the same as above, though the gradients of the top and bottom lines are more symmetric. The example is enlarged to show the effect.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions.DrawPathPixelOffset
member.summary:
Gets or sets the pixel offset to use before applying the Pen.Width when drawing a shape.
Default value: .
See the online help for image examples.

remarks.para: When drawing a shape, the pen width is applied around the path. When the value of this property is , the point coordinates of the path are shifted by half a pixel before applying the pen width.
When is and is , and all points are at integer coordinates, the value of this property makes no difference.

example.para:
The following images provide a few examples:
DescriptionImage Example
= PixelOffset.None (default): When drawing paths, the point coordinates are not adjusted before applying the pen width. When is , for polygons with every point at integer coordinates, this causes blurry horizontal and vertical lines for odd pen widths and sharp ones for even pen widths. The left rectangle was drawn with a 1 pixel wide pen, and the right one with a 2 pixel wide pen.
= PixelOffset.Half: The point coordinates are shifted by a half pixel right and down before applying the pen width. When is , for polygons with every point at integer coordinates, this causes sharp horizontal and vertical lines for odd pen widths and blurry ones for even pen widths. The left rectangle was drawn with a 1 pixel wide pen, and the right one with a 2 pixel wide pen.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions.Quantizer
member.summary:
Gets or sets an instance to use when drawing shapes.
Default value: .
See the Examples section of the property for an example.

remarks.para: Setting a quantizer allows using fewer colors than the target supports. Even when this property is , the colors are automatically quantized to the target's supported color range.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions.Ditherer
member.summary:
Gets or sets an instance to use when drawing shapes.
Default value: .
See the online help for an example with images.

remarks.para: If the target does not support the color depth of the drawn shape, or when is also set, setting a ditherer can help to preserve the original details.
If is , and the target is not a low-color bitmap, then this property might be ignored.

example.para:
The example above may produce the following results:
DescriptionImage Example
Ditherer is . The colors are automatically quantized to the black and white target. Cyan becomes white, whereas blue becomes black.
Using . The shades of cyan and blue appear in dithering patterns.
Using dithering. The shades of cyan and blue appear in dithering patterns.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions.CacheRegionLimit
member.summary:
Gets or sets the maximum pixel size for caching the region of a instance. If the region has more pixels than this value, it will be re-scanned in each drawing session.
Default value: 16777216, which is 16 MB for anti-aliased regions or 2 MB for aliased regions.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Path
member.summary:
Represents the path of a custom shape to be drawn or filled. The path can consist of multiple open or closed figures.
See the online help for an example with image.

remarks.para: Though you can use the dedicated methods of the class to draw or fill simple shapes, the class provides a more effective way to define custom shapes. The class can be used to define complex shapes consisting of multiple figures, which can be then drawn or filled in a single operation.

But even if you need to draw or fill a simple shape multiple times, using a instance can be more effective, because the region of the path can be cached for faster drawing. The caching can be enabled by setting the property to .
remarks.note: Please note that in some cases , the class can be less effective than using the dedicated methods of the class. For example, drawing 1 pixel wide lines with no anti-aliasing may use a different algorithm that never uses caching. Also, very large regions may not be cached (this can be adjusted by the DrawingOptions.CacheRegionLimit property).

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Path.AddPoint(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Adds a point to the current figure of this instance.
member.param: The x-coordinate of the point to add.
The y-coordinate of the point to add.
member.returns: This instance.

remarks.para: If the current figure is empty, the added point will be the starting point of the figure. Otherwise, the added point will be connected to the last point of the figure.

When the is filled, the figures require at least 3 non-collinear points to be rendered. When the is drawn, even a single point is rendered. If the Pen.Width is 1, it means drawing a single pixel, in which case it's much faster to use the IWritableBitmapData.SetColor32 method instead.
The parameters are not validated here but in the moment of drawing the coordinates of the possibly transformed path points must fall into the bounds of an int value; otherwise, an will be thrown.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Path.AddPoint(System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary: Adds a point to the current figure of this instance.
member.param: The point to add.
member.returns: This instance.

remarks.para: If the current figure is empty or closed, the added point will be the starting point of a new figure. Otherwise, the added point will be connected to the last point of the figure.

When the is filled, the figures require at least 3 non-collinear points to be rendered. When the is drawn, even a single point is rendered. If the Pen.Width is 1, it means drawing a single pixel, in which case it's much faster to use the IWritableBitmapData.SetColor32 method instead.
The parameter is not validated here but in the moment of drawing the coordinates of the possibly transformed path points must fall into the bounds of an int value; otherwise, an will be thrown.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Path.AddLine(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Adds a line to the current figure of this instance.
member.param: The x-coordinate of the starting point of the line to add.
The y-coordinate of the starting point of the line to add.
The x-coordinate of the end point of the line to add.
The y-coordinate of the end point of the line to add.
member.returns: This instance.

remarks.para: If the current figure is not empty or closed, the added line will be connected to the last point of the figure.
When the is filled, a single line is not rendered. When the is drawn, the right/bottom values of the coordinates are inclusive, so even a single pixel line is rendered.
The parameters are not validated here but in the moment of drawing the coordinates of the possibly transformed path points must fall into the bounds of an int value; otherwise, an will be thrown.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Path.AddLines(System.Drawing.PointF[])
member.summary: Adds a series of connected lines to the current figure of this instance.
member.param: The points of the line segments to add to the current figure of this .
member.returns: This instance.
member.exception: is .

remarks.para: The first point of the array will be the starting point of the first line segment. Each additional point specifies the endpoint of a line segment, whose starting point is the endpoint of the previous line.
If the current figure is not empty or closed, the added lines will be connected to the last point of the figure.
The are not validated here but in the moment of drawing the coordinates of the possibly transformed path points must fall into the bounds of an int value; otherwise, an will be thrown.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Path.GetPoints
member.summary: Gets the points of the figures in this instance.
member.returns: The points of the figures in this instance.

remarks.para: The returned list contains the points of the figures in the order they were added to the instance. Every figure is represented by an array of flattened points that can be interpreted as a series of connected lines.
If a figure is closed and has at least 3 points, then it is ensured that the last point of the figure is the same as the first point.
This method can be used to provide a bridge between the class and other graphics libraries or APIs.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Path.CloseFigure
member.summary: Closes the current figure. If the current figure is empty or already closed, this method has no effect.
member.returns: This instance.

remarks.para: Closing a figure means that the last point of the figure will be connected to the first point of the figure. This makes a different from StartFigure only when the is drawn, because filling always treats the figures as if they were closed.
After calling this method the next added element will always start a new figure.
A single point or a line section is always interpreted as an open figure. If the current figure has only a point or a single line, this method has the same effect as StartFigure.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Path.StartFigure
member.summary:
Starts a new figure without closing the current figure. If the current figure is empty, this method has no effect.
See also the Remarks section of the CloseFigure method for details.
member.returns: This instance.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Pen
member.summary:
Represents a pen for drawing operations.
See the online help for image examples.

remarks.para: s are used to draw the outline of shapes, or to draw primitive lines and curves.

A instance is defined by a (possibly implicitly by a single color) that determines the color or texture of the pen, and a that determines the width of the pen. The , , , and properties determine how the ends and joins of lines are drawn.

example.para:
The following table illustrates the behavior of some properties of the class:
DescriptionImage Example
: Specifies how to join the consecutive line segments. Can be , or . The example images demonstrate these join types from the top to the bottom. All examples use a 10 pixel wide pen.
and : Specify the style of the start and end points of an open figure. Can be , , or . The example images demonstrate these cap types from the top to the bottom, using the same cap style at both ends. Please note that the only difference between and styles is that the style has the originally specified length, whereas the style extends the line by half of the pen width. All examples use a 10 pixel wide pen.
: It allows setting a explicitly, so the can use not only a solid color but also a texture or any other brush. The example demonstrates a 10 pixel wide pen with a diagonal linear gradient brush using mirrored wrapping mode.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Pen.Brush
member.summary:
Gets or sets the that determines the color or texture of the .
Default value: The instance that was either passed to the corresponding constructor, or was created implicitly from a color by the other constructors.
See the Examples section of the class for image examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Pen.Width
member.summary:
Gets or sets the width of the .
Default value: the width that was passed to the constructor, or 1, if it was not specified.

remarks.para: A with of 1/64 or less is not visible. If is and is , then a width less than 1/4 is not visible.

member.summary:

Default value: .

member.summary:
If the is , then gets or sets the limit for the ratio of the miter length to half the that determines whether the join is beveled or mitered. Makes a difference only if the is greater than 1.
Default value: 10.

member.summary: null: newly created, IsGenerated returns false and creates an unset handle. Not set: IsGenerated blocks on the current thread until generating is still in progress in another thread, and then returns true Set: IsGenerated returns true, generating is complete

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.GradientWrapMode
member.summary:
Represents the mode how a gradient is treated when the gradient area is exceeded.
See the online help for image examples.

example.para:
The following table demonstrates the possible values and their effect:
DescriptionImage Example
: The gradient stops at the specified start and end points, and the exceeding area is simply filled with the specified end colors in both directions. In this example a horizontal gradient is drawn from 20 to 80, using color space from red to blue.
: The gradient is clipped at the specified start and end points, as if the exceeding area was transparent. This example is the same gradient as above, but with wrap mode.
: The gradient is repeated beyond the specified start and end points. In this example a diagonal gradient is drawn from (-10, 10) to (10, -10), using color space from white to black.
: The gradient is mirrored beyond the specified start and end points. This example is the same gradient as above, but with wrap mode.
example.note:
A value is used only when the gradient is specified by two points. When just an angle is specified, the gradient is always stretched to the bounds of the shape.
See the Examples section of the method for an example for such a gradient.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.GradientWrapMode.Stop
member.summary: The gradient stops at the specified start and end points, and the exceeding area is simply filled with the specified end colors in both directions.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.GradientWrapMode.Clip
member.summary: The gradient is clipped at the specified start and end points, as if the exceeding area was transparent.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.GradientWrapMode.Repeat
member.summary: The gradient is repeated beyond the specified start and end points.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.GradientWrapMode.Mirror
member.summary: The gradient is mirrored beyond the specified start and end points.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.LineCapStyle.Square

See the Examples section of the class for image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.LineJoinStyle.Miter
member.summary: Represents a miter join. This produces a sharp corner or a bevel join if the miter limit is exceeded.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.LineJoinStyle.Bevel
member.summary: Represents a bevel join, which produces a diagonal corner.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.LineJoinStyle.Round
member.summary: Represents a round join, which produces a rounded corner.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.PixelOffset
member.summary:
Represents pixel offset strategies for the DrawingOptions.ScanPathPixelOffset and DrawingOptions.DrawPathPixelOffset properties.
See the Remarks section of the DrawingOptions.ScanPathPixelOffset and DrawingOptions.DrawPathPixelOffset properties for details and image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.PixelOffset.None
member.summary: When scanning the region of a path (see DrawingOptions.ScanPathPixelOffset), it specifies that the scanning of edges should be performed at the top of the pixels. When drawing a path (see DrawingOptions.DrawPathPixelOffset), it specifies that the points of the drawn path are not adjusted before applying the pen width.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.PixelOffset.Half
member.summary: When scanning the region of a path (see DrawingOptions.ScanPathPixelOffset), it specifies that the scanning of edges should be performed at the center of the pixels. When drawing a path (see DrawingOptions.DrawPathPixelOffset), it specifies that the points of the drawn path are shifted by a half pixel before applying the pen width.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.ShapeFillMode
member.summary:
Specifies how to the interior of a path is filled when it contains intersecting edges. If a path has no intersecting edges, then both strategies produce the same result.
See the Remarks section of the DrawingOptions.FillMode property for image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.ShapeFillMode.Alternate
member.summary: Specifies the alternate fill mode. If a scanline of the region to fill crosses an odd number of path segments, the starting point is inside the closed region and is therefore part of the fill area. An even number of crossings means that the point is not in an area to be filled. This strategy is faster than the mode, though it may produce "holes" when a polygon has self-crossing lines.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.ShapeFillMode.NonZero
member.summary: Specifies the nonzero fill mode. It considers the direction of the path segments at each intersection. It adds one for every clockwise intersection, and subtracts one for every counterclockwise intersection. If the result is nonzero, the point is considered inside the fill area. A zero count means that the point lies outside the fill area. This strategy is slower than the mode, though it makes a difference in the result only when the path to fill has intersections.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.TextureMapMode
member.summary:
Represents the possible modes how a texture is mapped when filling a shape by a texture .
See the online help for image examples.

example.para:
The following table demonstrates the possible values and their effect:
DescriptionImage Example
: The texture is tiled using the same orientation. DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending is , so the transparent pixels of the texture don't affect the background.
: The texture is tiled, mirroring the adjacent tiles horizontally in each row. DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending is , so the transparent pixels of the texture don't affect the background.
: The texture is tiled, mirroring the adjacent tiles vertically in each column. DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending is , so the transparent pixels of the texture don't affect the background.
: The texture is tiled, mirroring the adjacent tiles horizontally in each row and vertically in each column. DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending is , so the transparent pixels of the texture don't affect the background.
: The texture is clipped to the shape without tiling. As in this example the texture does not cover the entire shape, the exceeding regions are simply handled as if they were transparent. As no offset is specified, the texture's location is the top-left corner of the target , so it can be seen only in the topmost ellipse. DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending is , so the transparent ellipses indicate the regions of the fill operations.
: Similar to , except that the exceeding regions are filled by extending the texture's edge pixels. In this example the texture does not have homogeneous colors at the edges, hence the stripes in the exceeding regions. DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending is , so the transparent ellipses indicate the regions of the fill operations.
: Same as , but the texture is always centered in the currently filled shape. DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending is , so the transparent ellipses indicate the regions of the fill operations.
: Similar to , but the texture is always centered in the currently filled shape. In this example the left edge of the texture completely transparent, so we don't see pixels extended to the left. DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending is , so the transparent ellipses indicate the regions of the fill operations.
: The texture is stretched to fill the entire shape. The texture's aspect ratio is not preserved. DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending is , so the small transparent regions didn't affect the background. DrawingOptions.AntiAliasing is also , so the stretching was performed with using an interpolation.
: Similar to , but the texture's aspect ratio is preserved. DrawingOptions.AlphaBlending is , so the transparent ellipses indicate the regions of the fill operations. DrawingOptions.AntiAliasing is , so the zooming was performed with the nearest neighbor algorithm.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.TextureMapMode.Tile
member.summary:
The texture is tiled, using the same orientation for each tile.
See the online help for image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.TextureMapMode.TileFlipX
member.summary:
The texture is tiled, mirroring the adjacent tiles horizontally in each row.
See the online help for image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.TextureMapMode.TileFlipY
member.summary:
The texture is tiled, mirroring the adjacent tiles vertically in each column.
See the online help for image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.TextureMapMode.TileFlipXY
member.summary:
The texture is tiled, mirroring the adjacent tiles horizontally in each row and vertically in each column.
See the online help for image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.TextureMapMode.Clip
member.summary:
The texture is clipped to the shape without tiling. If the texture does not cover the entire shape, the exceeding regions are simply handled as if they were transparent. If no offset is specified, the texture's location is the top-left corner of the target , regardless of the shape's location.
See the online help for image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.TextureMapMode.Extend
member.summary:
The texture is clipped to the shape without tiling. If the texture does not cover the entire shape, the exceeding regions are filled by extending the texture's edge pixels. If no offset is specified, the texture's location is the top-left corner of the target , regardless of the shape's location.
See the online help for image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.TextureMapMode.Center
member.summary:
Similar to , but the texture is always centered in the currently filled shape. If there is an offset specified, it is applied relative to the center of the shape.
See the online help for image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.TextureMapMode.CenterExtend
member.summary:
Similar to , but the texture is always centered in the currently filled shape. If there is an offset specified, it is applied relative to the center of the shape.
See the online help for image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.TextureMapMode.Stretch
member.summary:
The texture is stretched to fill the entire shape. The texture's aspect ratio is not preserved. if DrawingOptions.AntiAliasing is , then the texture is resized with an automatically selected interpolation; otherwise, the texture is resized using the nearest neighbor algorithm. The used color space for resizing depends on the of the original texture. Please note that this generates a new texture for each shape, so it can be slow for large shapes.
See the online help for image examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.TextureMapMode.Zoom
member.summary:
Similar to , but the texture's aspect ratio is preserved. If the texture does not cover the entire shape, the exceeding regions are simply handled as if they were transparent.
See the online help for image examples.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.BitmapDataExtensions
member.summary: Provides extension methods for the type that are related to shape drawing and filling.

remarks.para: To obtain an instance, use the class, or the GetReadWriteBitmapData extension methods of the various platform-dependent packages.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.BitmapDataExtensions.DrawLine(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadWriteBitmapData,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions)
member.summary: Draws a one-pixel wide line between two points with the specified .
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The color of the line to draw.
The x-coordinate of the starting point.
The y-coordinate of the starting point.
The x-coordinate of the end point.
The y-coordinate of the end point.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.para: The right/bottom values of the coordinates are inclusive, so if the start and end points are the same, a single pixel will be drawn.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the line directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the line to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same line is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginDrawLine or DrawLineAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

member.exception: is .
A is created internally and the width or height of Path.Bounds overflows.

This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

A shortcut is possible when the specified has a width between 0.25 and 1, it uses a solid with an opaque color, and if is either , or its is enabled in , it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same line is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.

This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.

remarks.para: The right/bottom values of the coordinates are inclusive, so if the start and end points are the same, a single pixel will be drawn.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the line directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the line to it. This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the lines directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the lines to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same lines are drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginDrawLines or DrawLinesAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the lines directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the lines to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same lines are drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.

This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An that represents the asynchronous operation, which could still be pending.

remarks.para: The first point of the array will be the starting point of the first line segment. Each additional point specifies the endpoint of a line segment, whose starting point is the endpoint of the previous line.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the lines directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the lines to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same lines are drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
In .NET Framework 4.0 and above you can use also the DrawLinesAsync methods.
To finish the operation and to get the exception that occurred during the operation you have to call the EndDrawLines method.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

If the lines are drawn by using a shortcut, then the operation is executed synchronously, it cannot be canceled, it is not parallelized, and there is no progress reporting, regardless of the parameter.

member.summary: Draws a series of one-pixel wide Bézier curves with the specified .
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The color of the curves to draw.
The points of the curves to draw.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.para: The allowed number of points in is 0, 1, or a multiple of 3 plus 1.

When has at least four items, the first four points define the first Bézier curve. Each additional three points define a new Bézier curve, where the last point of the previous curve is the starting point of the next curve.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the curves directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the curves to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same Bézier curves are drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginDrawBeziers or DrawBeziersAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

member.exception: or is .
The number of points is not a multiple of 3 plus 1.
A is created internally and the width or height of Path.Bounds overflows.
