member.summary: Draws a series of one-pixel wide Bézier curves with the specified asynchronously.
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The color of the curves to draw.
The points of the curves to draw.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: A task that represents the asynchronous operation. Its result is , if the operation completed successfully, or , if the operation has been canceled and the ThrowIfCanceled property in parameter was .

remarks.para: The allowed number of points in is 0, 1, or a multiple of 3 plus 1.

When has at least four items, the first four points define the first Bézier curve. Each additional three points define a new Bézier curve, where the last point of the previous curve is the starting point of the next curve.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the curves directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the curves to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same Bézier curves are drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

If the curves are drawn by using a shortcut, then the operation is executed synchronously, it cannot be canceled, it is not parallelized, and there is no progress reporting, regardless of the parameter.

The number of points is not a multiple of 3 plus 1.
The coordinates (after a possible transformation specified in ) are outside the bounds of an int value.
The operation has been canceled and the ThrowIfCanceled property in was . This exception is thrown when the result is awaited.

member.summary: Draws a one-pixel wide polygon with the specified .
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The color of the polygon to draw.
The vertices of the polygon to draw.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.para: Every pair of two consecutive points specifies a side of the polygon. In addition, if the last point and the first point do not coincide, they specify the last side of the polygon.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the polygon directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the points to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same polygon is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginDrawPolygon or DrawPolygonAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

remarks.para: Every pair of two consecutive points specifies a side of the polygon. In addition, if the last point and the first point do not coincide, they specify the last side of the polygon.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the polygon directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the points to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same polygon is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
In .NET Framework 4.0 and above you can use also the DrawPolygonAsync methods.
To finish the operation and to get the exception that occurred during the operation you have to call the EndDrawPolygon method.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

If the polygon is drawn by using a shortcut, then the operation is executed synchronously, it cannot be canceled, it is not parallelized, and there is no progress reporting, regardless of the parameter.

member.summary: Draws a one-pixel wide rectangle with the specified .

The height of the rectangle.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.para: When drawing a one-pixel wide rectangle, the right/bottom values of the coordinates are inclusive, so if and are zero, a single pixel will be drawn.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the rectangle directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the rectangle to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same rectangle is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginDrawRectangle or DrawRectangleAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.

member.summary: Begins to draw a one-pixel wide rectangle with the specified asynchronously.
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The color of the rectangle to draw.
The rectangle to draw.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An that represents the asynchronous operation, which could still be pending.

remarks.para: When drawing a one-pixel wide rectangle, the right/bottom values of the coordinates are inclusive, so if the width and height are zero, a single pixel will be drawn.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the rectangle directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the rectangle to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same rectangle is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
In .NET Framework 4.0 and above you can use also the DrawRectangleAsync methods.
To finish the operation and to get the exception that occurred during the operation you have to call the EndDrawRectangle method.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

If the rectangle is drawn by using a shortcut, then the operation is executed synchronously, it cannot be canceled, it is not parallelized, and there is no progress reporting, regardless of the parameter.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the ellipse directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the ellipse to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same ellipse is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.

This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.

member.param: The instance to draw on.

The bounding rectangle that defines the ellipse.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An that represents the asynchronous operation, which could still be pending.

remarks.para: When drawing a one-pixel wide ellipse, the right/bottom values of the bounding rectangle are inclusive, so if the width and height are zero, a single pixel will be drawn.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the ellipse directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the ellipse to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same ellipse is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
In .NET Framework 4.0 and above you can use also the DrawEllipseAsync methods.
To finish the operation and to get the exception that occurred during the operation you have to call the EndDrawEllipse method.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

If the ellipse is drawn by using a shortcut, then the operation is executed synchronously, it cannot be canceled, it is not parallelized, and there is no progress reporting, regardless of the parameter.

remarks.para: This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the arc directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the arc to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same arc is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.

To finish the operation and to get the exception that occurred during the operation you have to call the EndDrawArc method.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

member.summary: Draws a one-pixel wide pie shape with the specified .

The y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the bounding rectangle that defines the ellipse from which the pie is drawn.
The width of the bounding rectangle that defines the ellipse from which the pie is drawn.
The height of the bounding rectangle that defines the ellipse from which the pie is drawn.
The starting angle of the pie shape, measured in degrees clockwise from the x-axis.
The sweep angle of the pie shape, measured in degrees clockwise from .

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.

remarks.para: The pie shape is defined by a partial outline of an ellipse and the two radial lines that intersect the endpoints of the partial outline.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the pie shape directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the pie to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same pie shape is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginDrawPie or DrawPieAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

A shortcut is possible when the specified has a width between 0.25 and 1, it uses a solid with an opaque color, and if is either , or its is enabled in , it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same pie shape is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginDrawPie or DrawPieAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. member.summary: Begins to draw a one-pixel wide pie shape with the specified asynchronously.
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The color of the pie to draw.
The bounding rectangle that defines the ellipse from which the pie is drawn.
The starting angle of the pie shape, measured in degrees clockwise from the x-axis.
The sweep angle of the pie shape, measured in degrees clockwise from .

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An that represents the asynchronous operation, which could still be pending.

remarks.para: The pie shape is defined by a partial outline of an ellipse and the two radial lines that intersect the endpoints of the partial outline.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the pie shape directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the pie to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same pie shape is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
In .NET Framework 4.0 and above you can use also the DrawPieAsync methods.
To finish the operation and to get the exception that occurred during the operation you have to call the EndDrawPie method.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

If the pie shape is drawn by using a shortcut, then the operation is executed synchronously, it cannot be canceled, it is not parallelized, and there is no progress reporting, regardless of the parameter.

A shortcut is possible when the specified has a width between 0.25 and 1, it uses a solid with an opaque color, and if is either , or its is enabled in , it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same pie shape is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

If the pie shape is drawn by using a shortcut, then the operation is executed synchronously, it cannot be canceled, it is not parallelized, and there is no progress reporting, regardless of the parameter.

remarks.para: When drawing a one-pixel wide rounded rectangle, the right/bottom values of the bounding rectangle are inclusive, so if and are zero, a single pixel will be drawn.

If is negative, the absolute value will be used. If it is greater than the half of the smaller side of the bounding rectangle, it will be adjusted to the half of the smaller side, so the result will be an oval shape. If the is 0, a simple rectangle will be drawn.

member.summary: Draws a one-pixel wide rounded rectangle with the specified , applying the same corner radius to all corners, and using a that may belong to a higher level, possibly asynchronous operation.

An IAsyncContext instance that contains information for asynchronous processing about the current operation.
The color of the rounded rectangle to draw.
The bounding rectangle that defines the rounded rectangle.
The size of the corner radius of the rounded rectangle for all corners.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns:
, if the operation completed successfully.
, if the operation has been canceled.

remarks.para: When drawing a one-pixel wide rounded rectangle, the right/bottom values of the bounding rectangle are inclusive, so if the width and height are zero, a single pixel will be drawn.

If is negative, the absolute value will be used. If it is greater than the half of the smaller side of the bounding rectangle, it will be adjusted to the half of the smaller side, so the result will be an oval shape. If the is 0, a simple rectangle will be drawn.

This method tries to use a shortcut to draw the rounded rectangle directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the rounded rectangle to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when is enabled in , and it specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same rounded rectangle is drawn repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.

This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

remarks.para: If the property of is not the identity matrix, then the path region is not cached, even if is enabled. To improve the performance of drawing transformed paths repeatedly, apply the transformations on the instance instead, and use the identity matrix in .

You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginDrawPath or DrawPathAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

member.summary: Fills a rectangle with the specified .
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The color of the rectangle to fill.
The x-coordinate of the upper-left corner.
The y-coordinate of the upper-left corner.
The width of the rectangle.
The height of the rectangle.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.para: When filling a rectangle, the right/bottom values of the coordinates are exclusive, so if or is zero, then nothing is drawn.

This method tries to use a shortcut to fill the rectangle directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the rectangle to it. A shortcut is possible when is and the specified is opaque, or when specifies that no anti-aliasing and no alpha blending is required, the transformation is the identity matrix, and neither nor is specified.
When no shortcut can be used and the same rectangle is filled repeatedly, creating a with enabled can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginFillRectangle or FillRectangleAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.

This method tries to use a shortcut to fill the rectangle directly, which is faster than creating a and adding the rectangle to it. The color of the ellipse to fill.
The x-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the bounding rectangle that defines the ellipse.
The y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the bounding rectangle that defines the ellipse.
The width of the bounding rectangle that defines the ellipse.
The height of the bounding rectangle that defines the ellipse.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.para: When filling an ellipse, the right/bottom values of the bounding rectangle are exclusive, so if or is zero, then nothing is drawn.
This method does not use optimized shortcuts. If the same ellipse is filled repeatedly, creating a with enabled and adding the ellipse to it can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginFillEllipse or FillEllipseAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

, if the operation completed successfully.

remarks.para: When filling an ellipse, the right/bottom values of the bounding rectangle are exclusive, so if the width or height is zero, then nothing is drawn.
This method does not use optimized shortcuts. If the same ellipse is filled repeatedly, creating a with enabled and adding the ellipse to it can provide a better performance.

This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.BitmapDataExtensions.BeginFillEllipse(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadWriteBitmapData,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Drawing.Rectangle,KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions,KGySoft.Threading.AsyncConfig)
member.summary: Begins to fill an ellipse with the specified asynchronously.
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The color of the ellipse to fill.
The bounding rectangle that defines the ellipse.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An that represents the asynchronous operation, which could still be pending.

remarks.para: When filling an ellipse, the right/bottom values of the bounding rectangle are exclusive, so if the width or height is zero, then nothing is drawn.
This method does not use optimized shortcuts. If the same ellipse is filled repeatedly, creating a with enabled and adding the ellipse to it can provide a better performance.
In .NET Framework 4.0 and above you can use also the FillEllipseAsync methods.
To finish the operation and to get the exception that occurred during the operation you have to call the EndFillEllipse method.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

The to use for filling the pie shape.
The bounding rectangle that defines the ellipse from which the pie shape comes.
The starting angle of the pie shape, measured in degrees clockwise from the x-axis.
The sweep angle of the pie shape, measured in degrees clockwise from .

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An that represents the asynchronous operation, which could still be pending.

remarks.para: The pie shape is defined by an arc of an ellipse and the two radial lines that intersect with the endpoints of the arc.
This method does not use optimized shortcuts. If the same pie shape is filled repeatedly, creating a with enabled and adding the pie to it can provide a better performance.
In .NET Framework 4.0 and above you can use also the FillPieAsync methods.
To finish the operation and to get the exception that occurred during the operation you have to call the EndFillPie method.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

member.param: The reference to the pending asynchronous request to finish.
member.returns:
, if the operation completed successfully.
, if the operation has been canceled and the ThrowIfCanceled property in the asyncConfig parameter was set to .
member.exception: The coordinates (after a possible transformation specified in ) are outside the bounds of an int value.
The operation has been canceled and the ThrowIfCanceled property in the asyncConfig parameter was .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.BitmapDataExtensions.FillRoundedRectangle(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadWriteBitmapData,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions)
member.summary: Fills a rounded rectangle with the specified , applying the same corner radius to all corners.
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The color of the rounded rectangle to fill.
The x-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the bounding rectangle that defines the rounded rectangle.
The y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the bounding rectangle that defines the rounded rectangle.
The width of the bounding rectangle that defines the rounded rectangle.
The height of the bounding rectangle that defines the rounded rectangle.
The size of the corner radius of the rounded rectangle for all corners.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.para: When filling a rounded rectangle, the right/bottom values of the bounding rectangle are exclusive, so if or is zero, then nothing is drawn.

If is negative, the absolute value will be used. If it is greater than the half of the smaller side of the bounding rectangle, it will be adjusted to the half of the smaller side, so the result will be an oval shape. If the is 0, a simple filled rectangle will be drawn.
This method does not use optimized shortcuts. If the same rounded rectangle is filled repeatedly, creating a with enabled and adding the rounded rectangle to it can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginFillRoundedRectangle or FillRoundedRectangleAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

member.exception: is .
The coordinates (after a possible transformation specified in ) are outside the bounds of an int value.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.BitmapDataExtensions.FillRoundedRectangle(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadWriteBitmapData,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions)
member.summary: Fills a rounded rectangle with the specified , applying a custom corner radius to each corner.
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The color of the rounded rectangle to fill.
The x-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the bounding rectangle that defines the rounded rectangle.
The y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the bounding rectangle that defines the rounded rectangle.
The width of the bounding rectangle that defines the rounded rectangle.
The height of the bounding rectangle that defines the rounded rectangle.
The size of the top-left corner radius of the rounded rectangle.
The size of the top-right corner radius of the rounded rectangle.
The size of the bottom-right corner radius of the rounded rectangle.
The size of the bottom-left corner radius of the rounded rectangle.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.para: When filling a rounded rectangle, the right/bottom values of the bounding rectangle are exclusive, so if or is zero, then nothing is drawn.

If a corner radius parameter is negative, its absolute value will be used. If the sum of any adjacent corner radius parameters is greater than the corresponding side of the bounding rectangle, then all corner radius parameters will be scaled down proportionally to fit into the bounding rectangle.
This method does not use optimized shortcuts. If the same rounded rectangle is filled repeatedly, creating a with enabled and adding the rounded rectangle to it can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. You can use the overloads that have a ParallelConfig parameter to configure these, while still executing the method synchronously. Alternatively, use the BeginFillRoundedRectangle or FillRoundedRectangleAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

member.exception: is .

member.summary: Fills a rounded rectangle with the specified , applying a custom corner radius to each corner.
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The color of the rounded rectangle to fill.
The bounding rectangle that defines the rounded rectangle.
The size of the top-left corner radius of the rounded rectangle.
The size of the top-right corner radius of the rounded rectangle.
The size of the bottom-right corner radius of the rounded rectangle.
The size of the bottom-left corner radius of the rounded rectangle.
A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used.

The configuration of the operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. If , then the degree of parallelization is configured automatically.
member.returns:
, if the operation completed successfully.
, if the operation has been canceled and the ThrowIfCanceled property of the parameter was .

remarks.para: When filling a rounded rectangle, the right/bottom values of the bounding rectangle are exclusive, so if the width or height is zero, then nothing is drawn.

If a corner radius parameter is negative, its absolute value will be used. If the sum of any adjacent corner radius parameters is greater than the corresponding side of the bounding rectangle, then all corner radius parameters will be scaled down proportionally to fit into the bounding rectangle.
This method does not use optimized shortcuts. If the same rounded rectangle is filled repeatedly, creating a with enabled and adding the rounded rectangle to it can provide a better performance.
remarks.note: This method blocks the caller as it executes synchronously, though the parameter allows configuring the degree of parallelism, cancellation and progress reporting. Use the BeginFillRoundedRectangle or FillRoundedRectangleAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to perform the operation asynchronously.

remarks.para: When filling a rounded rectangle, the right/bottom values of the bounding rectangle are exclusive, so if the width or height is zero, then nothing is drawn.

If is negative, the absolute value will be used. If it is greater than the half of the smaller side of the bounding rectangle, it will be adjusted to the half of the smaller side, so the result will be an oval shape. If the is 0, a simple filled rectangle will be drawn.
This method does not use optimized shortcuts. If the same rounded rectangle is filled repeatedly, creating a with enabled and adding the rounded rectangle to it can provide a better performance.
In .NET Framework 4.0 and above you can use also the FillRoundedRectangleAsync methods.
To finish the operation and to get the exception that occurred during the operation you have to call the EndFillRoundedRectangle method.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.BitmapDataExtensions.FillRoundedRectangleAsync(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadWriteBitmapData,KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.Brush,System.Drawing.RectangleF,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.DrawingOptions,KGySoft.Threading.TaskConfig)
member.summary: Fills a rounded rectangle with the specified asynchronously, applying a custom corner radius to each corner.
member.param: The instance to draw on.
The to use for filling the rounded rectangle.
The bounding rectangle that defines the rounded rectangle.
The size of the top-left corner radius of the rounded rectangle.
The size of the top-right corner radius of the rounded rectangle.
The size of the bottom-right corner radius of the rounded rectangle.
The size of the bottom-left corner radius of the rounded rectangle.

A instance that specifies the drawing options to use. If , then the default options are used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: A task that represents the asynchronous operation. Its result is , if the operation completed successfully, or , if the operation has been canceled and the ThrowIfCanceled property in parameter was .

remarks.para: When filling a rounded rectangle, the right/bottom values of the bounding rectangle are exclusive, so if the width or height is zero, then nothing is drawn.

If a corner radius parameter is negative, its absolute value will be used. If the sum of any adjacent corner radius parameters is greater than the corresponding side of the bounding rectangle, then all corner radius parameters will be scaled down proportionally to fit into the bounding rectangle.
This method does not use optimized shortcuts. If the same rounded rectangle is filled repeatedly, creating a with enabled and adding the rounded rectangle to it can provide a better performance.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

remarks.para: If the property of is not the identity matrix, then the path region is not cached, even if is enabled. To improve the performance of filling transformed paths repeatedly, apply the transformations on the instance instead, and use the identity matrix in .

This method blocks the caller thread but if belongs to an async top level method, then the execution may already run on a pool thread. Degree of parallelism, the ability of cancellation and reporting progress depend on how these were configured at the top level method. To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the AsyncContextWrapper class.

Alternatively, you can use this method to specify the degree of parallelism for synchronous execution. For example, by passing AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext to the parameter the method will be forced to use a single thread only.
When reporting progress, this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the AsyncHelper class for details about how to create a context for possibly async top level methods.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Shapes.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
The namespace provides types and extension methods for drawing and filling shapes on instances.
See the properties of the class, and the Remarks section of the , and classes for examples with images.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.ColorChannels
member.summary: Represents the RGB color channels when manipulating images.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ColorChannels.None
member.summary: Represents none of the color channels.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ColorChannels.R
member.summary: Represents the Red color channel.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ColorChannels.G
member.summary: Represents the Green color channel.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ColorChannels.B
member.summary: Represents the Blue color channel.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ColorChannels.Rgb
member.summary: Represents the R, G and B color channels.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingOperation
member.summary: Represents various drawing operations to indicate the current operation when reporting progress using an IAsyncProgress implementation. This library always uses the type as a type argument when calling the New<T>(T, int, int) method.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingOperation.UndefinedProcessing
member.summary: Represents indefinite processing

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingOperation.InitializingQuantizer
member.summary: Represents the initialization of a quantizer

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingOperation.InitializingDitherer
member.summary: Represents the initialization of a ditherer

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingOperation.GeneratingPalette
member.summary: Represents a palette-generating operation. Can be the part of another operation, such as quantizer initialization.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingOperation.ProcessingPixels
member.summary: Represents an operation that processes pixels. A more complex async method may perform multiple processing operations one after another.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingOperation.Saving
member.summary: Represents a saving operation.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingOperation.Loading
member.summary: Represents a loading operation.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode
member.summary: Represents the scaling mode when an image needs to be resized.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Auto
member.summary: Represents an automatically selected scaling mode based on source/target sizes providing the best quality. In practice, the scaling mode is selected if either the width or height is enlarged, and the scaling mode, if there is shrinking in both dimensions. If source and target sizes are the same, then is selected.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.NoScaling
member.summary: Represents no scaling. When source and target sizes are different, then clipping might occur.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Represents the nearest neighbor scaling mode, which always selects the closest pixel when scaling. Apart from this is the fastest scaling mode but provides the poorest quality.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Box
member.summary: Represents box scaling mode. When downscaling, the pixels will average. When upscaling, the result is identical to .

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Bilinear
member.summary: Represents a 2-dimensional linear interpolation scaling mode. It is among the faster scaling techniques but it provides an acceptable quality only if the difference between the source and target size does not exceed 25%.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Bicubic
member.summary: Represents the bicubic interpolation. It both preserves sharpness and reduces artifacts quite well. This is the default scaling mode when downscaling images.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Lanczos2
member.summary: Represents the resampling algorithm suggested by Kornél Lánczos using a kernel radius of 2 pixels. It both preserves sharpness and reduces artifacts quite well. When downscaling, acts also as a low-pass filter. The result is usually similar to the bicubic filter.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Lanczos3
member.summary: Represents the resampling algorithm suggested by Kornél Lánczos using a kernel radius of 3 pixels. It is among the slower filters and it tends to increase the sharpness of the original image.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Spline
member.summary: Represents the spline cubic interpolation. It provides smooth results but it tends to overly blur the details.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.CatmullRom
member.summary: Represents the Catmull-Rom cubic interpolation. Similarly to the bicubic interpolation it preserves sharpness quite well without producing strong artifacts.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.MitchellNetravali
member.summary: Represents the Mitchell-Netravali cubic interpolation. Usually it produces very good results. This is the default scaling mode when upscaling images.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Robidoux
member.summary: Represents the Robidoux cubic interpolation. It produces a very similar result to the Mitchell-Netravali interpolation.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.IntExtensions
member.summary: In fact, Int32, UInt32, UInt64, BitVector32

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.RectangleExtensions.IsEmpty(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Gets whether the rectangle has zero Width OR Height. Not just faster than the IsEmpty property but also works better when Intersect returns a non-default practically zero rectangle.
